output: Mr. President, dear colleagues, I once again apologize for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of all and the understanding that education, knowledge, and the interplay of different cultures with one another are crucial is already a given fact.
For this very reason, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus program also plays its part, and in this new perspective, the new regulation is already in place.

The Erasmus Mundus program constitutes a significant contribution to the creation of centers of excellence in the EU, which will, to some extent, help stem the brain drain from the European Union. It also plays a notable role in...

in promoting European values among nationals from third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent an unparalleled cultural and linguistic diversity, which serves as a unique and attractive pole distinct from models existing in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have struggled greatly to survive.

The issue of visas for Erasmus students in the Schengen Area and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them often lead to a semi-clandestine situation within the European Union. This is because they are often master's students but hold tourist visas, sometimes even expired ones.
I consider it of the utmost relevance and urgency to seek a solution that ensures solidity, transparency, and effectiveness in the issuance of student visas.
Knowledge of the language that enables cultural perception and mutual coexistence, beyond strict academic mastery, is also crucial, which is why we can absolutely guarantee this premise.
To conclude, a word of thanks to Deputy Dessa Arnez for the manner in which she conducted this entire process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for the granting of state aids for the modernization and renewal of the fishing fleets of the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009 or should be in force for an indefinite period.
The specific characteristics of fishing activities in these regions warrant the extension of such aid beyond 2009, without causing any significant harm to the marine environment.
State aids for the modernization and renewal of fleets in the outermost regions for an indefinite period do not imply permanent and eternal aids.
would be immediately discontinued if studies and assessment by the Scientific Council and Regional Advisory Boards highlighted such a need.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fisheries in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that underpin the exclusive fishing reserve up to 10 miles for the fishermen of each OOP (Outermost Regions) also justify differentiated treatment regarding aids for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, the Fisheries Committee has found the best solutions that can address the specific characteristics of fisheries in the outermost regions. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Almunia, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, I would like to congratulate not only the rapporteurs but also the Commission for the initiative of producing this text, the review of the 10 years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
This is a strategic text, and this analysis was crucial.
The euro, as has been stated here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the euro has proven its resilience and strength even during the severe turbulence we have witnessed, and it is clearly important that the borders of this club be expanded.
But the times we live in continually test the solidity of the European project in many other dimensions.
The euro, as mentioned, is a central instrument in the functioning of the financial system.

However, the Commission's text itself clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in terms of both social and spatial aspects, kept pace with this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that disparities have violently intensified during the single currency's decade of operation.
This divergence affects regions of my country in particular, specifically northern Portugal, but also other regions of member states.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, notably through the extremely high exchange rate, have affected more severely the regions that are most exposed to international competition and the most export-oriented regions.
Today, the crisis that resulted from the deregulation of financial markets is violently impacting the real economy and further exacerbating the situation of many citizens and regions.

These regions, those exposed to international competition, those reliant on small and medium-sized enterprises, where access to credit is most crucial, are today victims of this process and are even threatening depression.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the confidence placed in it by European citizens.
The most powerful European countries have already initiated processes to relaunch their national economies.
We have the particular case of initiatives related to the automotive industry.
But Europe is more than that.
It must be far more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
The time has come to transform the euro into a central tool for Europe, supporting a strong currency but also a robust real economy, and to ensure the proper functioning of the euro.
of mechanisms that ensure the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it lies at the heart, it is the core of the European project.
The debate on the coordination of economic policies in the euro area today has an enhanced and undeniable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

Having a Lisbon strategy that is a sum of national initiatives and a stability and growth pact that imposes differing constraints on the various countries that use it and must submit to it, are limitations to which is added the limited budget we have.
Crises generate opportunities.
The Monetary Union can only be sustained by a convergence of the well-being of the member states that comprise it, independently of their citizens, regardless of where they were born.
What other way could we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must live up to its own diagnosis, and that is why we are eagerly awaiting the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this plenary session on November 26th and present to European citizens.

It is essential that, emerging from this crisis, a new phase of the Union be launched in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by effective prosperity made up of cohesion and also economic citizenship.

Thank you, Mr. President, Ms. Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question put to the European Commission by Gerardo Galiotta on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development of this Parliament is fully justified and relevant.

In fact, it is necessary to clarify the reasons that lead the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund insofar as it is unable to reach an agreement on a common position that would allow the legislative process to continue.
It is difficult to discontinue the reasons that may underlie the Council's position, except perhaps for petty financial reasons.
Does the Council not desire a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters as they occur?
I do not want this type of celebrated response to be the norm for other kinds of catastrophes, such as severe industrial accidents, terrorist attacks, or grave public health situations.

It is important that these issues have a clear response, just as it is important to clarify what the European Commission thinks about this situation and whether it intends to take any action to unlock the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this domain.
Citizens would not understand at all if it were not the case.
I wish to state that I wanted to protest against the declaration made by Ms. Luling, which seeks to condition the vote of the deputies in this House, and such conditioning makes no sense.

The interpretation you are making is one that we do not share, and it is in this regard that I would like to ask colleagues who know what they are addressing, who are aware that we are upholding other interests—those of public health, the interests of citizens, and the interests of countries—to indeed vote in favor of the report. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, for two months now, the political and media agendas have been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic regarding the Lisbon Treaty are barely reported in the media.

Don't you think that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be strengthened by the need and urgency of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, also as a political response to address and overcome the crisis we are living through?
Madam Acting President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, the world's powers currently have the international financial system in their hands.
They seek to lay hands on it, and it was about time.
And, therefore, perhaps it is time for us to finally address another problem that we have been hearing about for decades.
For decades we have heard this music of the ignoble plundering of resources, how many times, as again now in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

I believe it is also time to pursue these companies, to target this immobile trade, to freeze the accounts through which the shameful profits from this mineral resource exploitation at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations flow and are deposited.
I fail to understand why these companies are not listed in the same manner as we already maintain a blacklist of terrorist organizations.
And I fail to understand why the international community is unable to pursue these businessmen, who, in reality, are not businessmen but genuine criminals who threaten regional and global security.
I encourage the French presidency and the Commission to support an international initiative in this regard. Thank you very much.
We heard it said several times here today that a crisis typically generates an opportunity, and so it is.
And, if we wish to seize the opportunity that lies before us, the agenda is straightforward to discern.
Firstly, as we know, at the European Union level, there is a need to introduce transparency mechanisms, regulation, and supervision in financial markets.
And it is not necessary for Commissioner Macrivi to launch further consultations, nor is it required for the Presidency to analyze and invoke additional studies.
more proposals. One only needs to look at the proposals that were timely made by the socialists and that many of them were eventually taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot be present in the global arena passively.
She must be an active agent in shaping the new international order. She must be the advocate of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as are currently the tax havens.
In third place, we heard the President of the Commission say here today that there is a reluctance to coordinate strategies at the level of the different states.
It is true that had we not heard, from many members of the Commission, for so long, that markets self-regulate, that the state should keep out,
that financial markets have no impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a more active and engaged spirit of solidarity among the different countries.
But today the proposal we have before us is merely a first step. If we compare it to the programs of China and the United States, on the other hand, it...
does not define clearly enough what the objective is, and the objective must be employment, and thirdly, because a European program cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to show Europe's citizens that Europe is a network of economic rights that protects them in times of crisis and in terms of security.
solidarity, a growth program, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that, at this moment, are not receiving the benefits of the interventions made in the banking sector.
The real economy is precisely this, and we Europeans are here to show citizens that Europe is also here, and above all, because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I appear before you to present the work that has been done in collaboration with all of you in this initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the development of this process, we can say that we have done our job.

to all, and in particular to the shadow rapporteur colleagues from the various political groups who worked hard to reach compromises for the future, to the Regional Development staff, always available, especially Miguel Tel Cremades and Elisa da Farra,

To the PSE team, Lila, and Petros, and the European Commission, which, always represented by the many diverse directorates-general required by such a comprehensive report, continuously and closely monitored the work and made great efforts to ensure its successful completion.

to my office and, very particularly, to Joana Benzinho, I extend my most sincere thanks on behalf of a more harmonious and structured development for coastal regions and tourism in the European Union.
The 27 member states of the European Union collectively have over 89,000 kilometers of coastal zone.

This presents a variety of very particular features that, according to their location, stand out either for their cosmopolitanism, if we are talking about cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen, or Stockholm, or

due to the challenges of being in peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions, with issues of connectivity to major urban areas or rapid desertification contexts, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands, or Madeira.
In one way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of a coast and coastal zone, and experiences daily the advantages and disadvantages associated with them.
According to available data, by 2010, approximately 75% of humanity will live in coastal zones.
According to the circuits and their interrelations, we define the 50 km straight-line distance that extends from the coastline to the inland areas.
Yes, regions and not maritime strips detached from an integrated vision that these matters so desperately need, and that our ancestors would also endorse.
Here, this entire population will concentrate in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, with the sole expectation that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated vision of the impact of tourism on coastal areas seized our minds and prompted us to take action.

In the current financial crisis context, where the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly insurmountable, tourism emerges as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal manner.

The regions that, for their development, have an overwhelming or total dependence on this sector see their activity threatened and look to the future with distrust. Especially since tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, coordinated measures must be taken, and the spirit in which the Treaty of Lisbon is imbued reflects this same trend.
However, waiting until the treaty enters into force to start acting is akin to waiting until the milk has spilled to cry over it.
The current political-tourist activity and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it demand from us urgent and effective action.

The fact that these are structurally dependent areas on tourism, as a job creator, even though employment is often seasonal, this labor-intensive activity cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

For this very reason, this report that we are presenting to you here and now, which was already of the greatest relevance and urgency when the Regional Development Committee of this House decided to promote it, must now be considered a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority, indeed, should be given to the numerous initiatives this entails, and I believe it warrants your explicit support, as already conveyed by other institutions, alongside the measures adopted in the emergency plan.

from the Commission, among which I highlight the revision of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock it is currently experiencing should, obviously, be addressed.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of these coastal areas' economies, ensuring their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the genuine integration of different sectoral policies such as the maritime sector, transportation, and...

energy, the cohesion instruments already in place, the new quality product policy that the CAP revision incorporates with the announcement of the Else Cheque report, and the new tourist products in these coastal areas, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an adequate and holistic vision for this policy should become a reality in the European Union in the near future.

And to conclude, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and rapid and effective action involving all partners and stakeholders already on the ground, can we ensure that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and future-oriented coastal tourism sector. Thank you very much.
Mr. Commissioner and Mrs. Minister, E-Justice is a significant step in accessing the law, justice, and the courts.
I would like to congratulate the initiative and commend the rapporteur and the French Presidency.

The Ex-Justice project was one of the topics under discussion, and it is up to Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project that will enable all citizens to access services from other Member States in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable, and native language manner.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice on cross-border and legal issues.
E-Justice should be coordinated and managed by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions from the various Member States and their liaison with this responsible unit.
The Ex-Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I welcome the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Barro, colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, the former headquarters Martin Rur, and the many former headquarters staff.
In December 2004, the Council adopted the Regulation setting standards for security features and biometric data in passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now, we have had to take new steps to combat the abduction and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, in accordance with the principle of one person, one passport, can be the fundamental means of winning this difficult and important battle.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children aged 6 and above is already a practice with a long tradition, and for this reason, it does not raise any objections from me.
As an advocate for the European cause, I believe that, on this matter, harmonization is important.
It reassures me to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which have long set the minimum age at six years for the collection of fingerprints, will not have to change their national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of passports, which is being strengthened today, does not end with the existence of the passport itself.

The passport, in and of itself, corresponds to an increase in security levels, ranging from the presentation of the necessary documents for passport issuance, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border control posts.
This report is another step towards affirming the rights of the individual and ensuring their safety.
Mr. President, firstly, I would like to greet the rapporteur Alexander Lambsdorff and the shadow rapporteurs, with special mention to Bárbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I deem it indispensable that we move towards the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must indeed move forward with the necessary specifics and precautions towards applying the essential rules of the internal market to defense industries, increasing transparency in the tenders organized and the contracts signed, involving Member States of the European Union.
But, at the same time, we must contribute to the development of conditions that enable greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in global markets.

Commissioner Macrifi. It seems important to me that, with this directive, we can ensure progress in the legal framework concerning public contracts in the fields of defense and security, advancing market construction.

internal, obviously respecting the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security, and in particular those of manufacturers of armaments, munitions, and security equipment, such as, for example, my own country.

Mr. President, I would also emphasize the provisions that enable easier access for small and medium-sized enterprises to this market, particularly through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thereby making greater progress with more impact and depth in the sector.

industrial for the creation of a true European market in the defense industries, which can also contribute to strengthening research and development not only in the defense industries but also in a range of European industries that benefit from the development of the defense industries.
To conclude, one can refer to the obvious articulation between defense industries and the Union's foreign policies.
But I would like to cite, regarding the DET, a recent intervention translating a classic Roman proverb: "If you want peace, prepare for war."

The European Union, being almost a peaceful superpower, we refer to these industries as defense industries rather than war industries, because we seek peace and not war, and thus also require defense industries.
Mr. Vice-President Barro, I agree with you, I agree with your dissatisfaction.

immigration, particularly in the Mediterranean, towards Italy. France has moved forward with a set of important bilateral cooperations, but other Member States have not.
It is necessary for the Commission to persist, without losing enthusiasm, in this policy of cooperation and aid to the Member States.
President, Commissioner, I will attempt to present the issues in a highly concise manner.
First point, the issue of the European Union's special monitoring mechanism for the tests, which, as has been mentioned here, ended on December 31, 2008.
What is lacking, Commissioner, is the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and prices, similar to what occurs in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against potential unfair practices, and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I ask for your attention to this matter, following the example set by other colleagues.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety standards, social standards, and environmental standards.
The RITS, for example, is a recent initiative that imposes even more constraints on us.
It is important that the Commission have a clear strategy that is visible and subject to monitoring to ensure that imported products meet identical requirements.
In what ways are these aspects being adequately addressed in the ongoing free trade agreements?
As for Maidin, can Maidin actually help to resolve this issue?
Third point: the European Union has launched an economic recovery plan to tackle the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this moment, what actions is the Commission preparing to take given that a series of other countries, such as China, are increasingly proliferating non-tariff barriers to prevent our European imports from accessing Chinese markets?

What proposal do you have regarding the update or adjustment of the Globalization Fund, as well as the available support within the structural funds frameworks, to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Final question, indeed, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner, I will finish shortly, raise awareness among her colleagues and the institutions dealing with European monetary policy to achieve a rebalancing? Thank you very much.
It is clear to us that we should applaud Obama's decision, the decision to close Guantánamo, to ban torture, illegal interrogations, and to suspend military trials.
However, dear colleague, who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese Socialist government do not feel any guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the opposite.

It was precisely now, under the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, and at the initiative of Minister Luís Amado, that the possibility and duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without conviction in Guantánamo was triggered.

This is what is truly important, this is what should be highlighted as an example to be followed by the other Member States of the European Union. It is crucial that tomorrow the resolution is approved by all the parties that make up this House so that, united, the decision can carry more weight.
Mr. President, I would like to extend my sincere thanks to Ms. Napolitano for the excellent report.

14 years after Barcelona and 5 years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, parliamentary power, civil society, and heads of government deciding together.
All with a desire to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent a potential for development and peace in the world.
Limiting their analysis solely to the economic and business aspects is a clear error.

Responding to growth crises naturally requires political action, but responding to humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens must provide answers to the world's problems.
The world demanded answers, and months later, we, as citizens and politicians, notably on a platform such as the Union for the Mediterranean, continue to be slow to react.

I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served as a learning opportunity and a chance to move forward, for only those who make mistakes learn, but speeding up the reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest in adopting this directive proposal lies primarily in how it can contribute to invigorating economic activity at the local level and supporting interventions in the social sphere.
This application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the field of housing, both in construction and renovation, enabling Member States that adopt it to reduce the cost for the end user.

The provision of local services, particularly by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the DIVA tax, retaining and creating more and better jobs by promoting the consumption of goods and services, thereby stimulating the economy itself.
The restoration activity, fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the very growth of tourism, can significantly benefit at the local level from this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate in the European internal market, which will help reduce the reservations of some Member States already observed at the Council level.
Therefore, I cannot agree to the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, regardless of the protest.

The prudent manner in which this proposal should be handled in the European Parliament must not provide an opportunity for governments with certain reservations about the European Commission's proposal to effectively exercise their right of veto, which European legislation still grants them in tax matters.
And thus, here it is prudent to reject amendments without much sense that only hinder the acceptance of the text.
As already mentioned here, not only is the excellent the enemy of the good, but he who wants everything loses everything.
This proposed directive is significant not only for the strengthening of local economies but also aligns with ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.
We therefore support the Commission's proposal as presented. This was, moreover, the sense of the vote, as I understand it, of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee.

I pay tribute to the work of the rapporteurs and call for the approval of this proposal in its exact terms as it came from the Commission and as it was voted on in the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee. Thank you very much.
The word is to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and indeed, that is what motivated me to speak. When she caricatured the intentions of the Czech Presidency.
No one wants to send women home. The issue is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
There are even associations that seek to defend them, women who are ignored, despised, discriminated against, because they want to dedicate themselves to their families, and we do not listen to them.
And this is a matter of freedom, a matter of freedom of choice that the left so often invokes, but which they seem to forget in this context.
It is a matter of respecting or not the freedom of orientation of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who wish to do so with a higher quality of life, more quality fatherhood, and more quality motherhood.
That is what our society also needs to do.
We will not get there, we will not solve the problems of people's birth rates and happiness with prejudices.
We resolve with policies tailored to reality and the spontaneous desires of people.
Let's not get there with an obsession with the State and the market.
Let's take a fair look at the family.
Commissioner, dear colleagues, the difficult situation at Quimonda was exacerbated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has been doing everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
And we would like the Bavarian Government to also demonstrate a high sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the Vila do Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese minister himself, Manuel Pinho, affirmed the great interest in making this company viable, which is so important for Portugal and for Europe, stating that Quimonda can be a competitive company at a global level.
Mr. President, the Portuguese Government's efforts will be maintained with a view to a solution that ensures the company's viability.
We expect the German governments, at both the federal and state levels, to engage effectively in resolving this issue.
As for me, I would like to underscore once again the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry on European soil.
that no national or state executive makes the mistake of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs within the territory of the Union.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to support the restructuring of major automotive industry groups, but the funds of the Union and the efforts of the European Commission cannot be exhausted by such aid.

Dear Commissioner, we urge the Commission to support Quimonda, overcoming any potential communication gaps. This is the appeal we make to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, with whom we share bonds of working relationships and political solidarity, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our fellow countryman and that of a significant portion of Quimonda's workers.

We should emphasize, before concluding, that Portuguese President Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was new hope regarding Qimonda. Additionally, as already mentioned by colleagues, it is important to highlight the significance of the economic sector in which Qimonda operates.
We take into account that the Portuguese government has expressed its willingness to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, considering the country's economic scale.
Ladies and gentlemen, let us help save Quimonda? Time is of the essence.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we live in may not be the most appropriate for discussing the Lisbon Strategy. However, there is no doubt that we need a strategy.
in a strategy that addresses the difficulties and challenges presented by the current crisis.
And that is what we also expect from the Commission.

It is indispensable that the Commission does not step away from this matter and, instead, has the capacity to articulate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the German-speaking countries.

It is indispensable to bear in mind that this is an industry, as has already been stated here, that is of interest to Europe due to its quality and value, the research it conducts, and the environmental quality also associated with it. It is indispensable that the Commission does not withdraw.
I endorse the invitation extended by my colleague Pineda for the Commissioner and the Commission to visit Portugal.

It is indispensable that the Commission bear in mind that, at this juncture, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from European authorities. They need to feel that European authorities are close at hand.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands of the situation. Instead, they want a Europe that has the audacity to roll up its sleeves and get down to work, helping them overcome difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, thank you very much. I also add my voice to the tributes to Jamonet, but I have asked to speak to commend the Mr. President for the statement he made regarding the European Day of Remembrance for Victims of Terrorism.
It was at my initiative that, five years ago, we adopted this approach, which the Council enshrined at a meeting on March 25th, following the tragic Madrid attacks.
but my intervention was an appeal.

I know that there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but little else.

And my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we anticipated, and unemployment will be higher than we foresaw.
There are good reasons to suppose that the anticipated European stimulus is insufficient, but it is already clear at this moment that it is taking far too long to reach citizens.
The position of the Parliament is strong and clear. It has been and I hope it will continue to be so.
Our goal is to preserve jobs and create new ones, with cohesion and solidarity, whether territorial or social.
And in this time of crisis, citizens cannot accept a Europe that does not provide answers, a Europe that is powerless before the problems they are facing.
What is it that the Parliament will ask the Commission?

It naturally follows from these reports that you should coordinate national interventions. It requests that you employ all means currently at your disposal to intervene, and it provides you with all the necessary conditions, as a budgetary entity, to make this happen.

Asks him to launch a clear European initiative for employment and tells him that it is important to have a timed agenda to implement financial market regulation measures, as well as to get credit flowing to the real economy.
But what is the Council waiting for?
The Council is asked, above all, to rediscover the political will that lies at the heart of building the European project.
The European Union is about competition, but it is equally about cohesion and solidarity.
And there cannot be a single market without this guarantee, solidarity, and cohesion.
It is for this reason that we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies we had prior to joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, anyone visiting sub-Saharan Africa can easily recognize in most countries the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations these services should serve.
The indicators continuously published at the international level never cease to confirm this.
And, in that respect, it is utterly disturbing to realize that simple gestures and even not very elaborate practices, not particularly costly, could be enough to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard, and we must always bear in mind that cooperation in the health sector is truly strategic and directly addresses not only one of the Millennium Goals but many of the Millennium Goals.

The Court of Auditors has noted that, I quote, "Community financing in favor of the health sector has not increased since the year 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite the commitments made by the Commission regarding the Millennium Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa."
Grasp this firmly.

And it acknowledged, I quote again, that the Commission contributed significantly, through its funding, to the establishment of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but it did not extend the same attention to strengthening health systems, which was foreseen as one of its priorities.
Finally, citation.

According to the Court, this occurred, I quote again, because the Commission did not have sufficient expertise in health matters to ensure that the financing of the aid it provided to this sector was used in the best way.
Conclude.
This is, therefore, a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors directly issues to the European Commission, and which I support.
For our part, I wish to reiterate this same challenge, now sustained by the objectivity of these data and this evaluation.
Health services already form part of our development assistance priorities, but they should increasingly do so, warranting an increase in their funding.

Optimizing the way aid is delivered, taking into account the seemingly opposing needs of coordination in its management and proximity to beneficiary populations, is to provide a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge, and it is in this spirit that I urge it.
Colleague Bowies, just a moment ago, delivered a poignant speech here and was able to put human faces to the cold, dry numbers of the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is for our cooperation to be able to put a look of joy and hope in these very faces.
And, for this, Madam Commissioner, it is indispensable that the health sector figures in our cooperation be different.
Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is truly a distressing situation.
It is a country that has experienced chronic instability for many years, which charted a path towards democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing went well, there was a coup d'état, a small internal war, and the country lives in great political, military, and social instability, with deep tensions and rivalries. Recently, there has also been a very concerning and increasingly evident presence of drug trafficking interests to all observers.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the bomb assassination of Chief of Staff Tagume Naoué, and also the murder, in particularly barbaric, if not savage, terms of President Nineviera.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity with their families, the people of Guinea-Bissau, and we mourn, strongly condemn these attacks.
We desire a return to normality, and the lesson I draw and would like to emphasize in the resolution is that impunity is not a solution.
In the past, regarding the murder of Asuman Mané and the newspaper Verissim Siabra, how was it that you turned a blind eye to ensuring the guilty were found and brought to justice?
evidently, he sought new sources.

And therefore, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that the responsible parties must be identified, the guilty must be brought to justice, and we must provide all the assistance that is necessary.

I would also like to draw attention, in conclusion, to the concern with which we have heard about the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk it already represents for the European Union, and the shocking presence, due to its evidentiality, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal to you to consider, in this context, our relationship with Cape Verde.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, great knowledge, but it is also highly vulnerable, and this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, the strengthening of the special partnership with Cape Verde is also highly significant in this context. Thank you very much.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I would first and foremost like to thank everyone for the work accomplished.

The three lines outlined in the Green Book—concentration, interconnection, and cooperation—can provide solutions to certain obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated with...

concentration of economic activity, inequalities in access to markets and services resulting from distance and the divisions imposed, whether by borders between Member States, especially those most disadvantaged, but also between regions.
We should, therefore, enhance the synergies between these policies through effective methods of assessing their territorial impact.

For this very reason, I have always advocated for the definition of supplementary qualitative indicators with the aim of improving the design and implementation of corresponding on-the-ground policies, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, GDP remains the sole eligibility criterion for receiving support from the structural funds.

However, this definition of supplementary indicators and the conduct of territorial assessments should not lead to more bureaucracy or delays, but rather to the simplification of the implementation of new policies and support actions for territorial cohesion.
The fifth interim report, and to conclude, Mr. President, makes specific reference to the transition regions situated between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It is important to note that these regions require a clearer status, with greater security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, in the context of this major debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I cannot fail to mention the very specific problematic of the outermost regions.

regions that, due to the conjunction and persistence of a series of geographical factors, exhibit significant economic and social vulnerability, particularly acute in the context of a severe international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would thus like to appeal to the European Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Hübner, to pay very close attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, namely in tourism, construction, and the rise in unemployment, would be crucial to enable a specific European response tailored to these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions that goes beyond the measures already announced under the economic and social cohesion policy for the majority of European regions.
a specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions.

President, dear colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the European Economic Relations Plan states that cohesion policy significantly contributes to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a means of recovering from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon strategy, aiming to achieve growth and employment.
All the activated instruments aim to achieve this purpose and accelerate the attainment of results.

In this regard, the extension of the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the streamlining of the European Social Fund are particularly responsible for addressing the multiple social and economic emergency situations that require support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be all the more effective the more complementary your actions and spheres are.

However, as no new funds or new lines of action on the ground were foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in combating unemployment and the rapid increase in competitive pressure in the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the Committee on Regional Development has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission now proposes.
Urgency was requested of us, however, on this matter. And in adopting this regulatory package, we took this into account. This cause has never shirked its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the many serious concerns that the current situation raises, in the interest of ensuring the swiftness of the process and the real benefits for citizens that the proposal aims to achieve, we abstain, for now, from presenting new proposals and amendments.
However, we caution that there is a need to initiate, immediately, an evaluation process of this fund with a view to a complementary review to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the crisis, among other aspects, has highlighted the significant imbalances between the countries of the eurozone, perhaps the main...

conclusion of the report on the Economic and Monetary Union ten years ago, but above all, the extreme vulnerability of the countries that, while belonging to the European Union, are not part of the eurozone.

Therefore, the strengthening of the resources available at European level to support balance of payments crisis situations is absolutely indispensable. Hence, we welcome the increase from 12 to 25, and then to 50 million euros in necessary resources.
However, what is more important is to address the root causes of the problems, not just their most evident manifestations.
Today, the enlarged Europe and the euro area must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the goals of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to assess the capacity of European horizontal policies in this light, but it is also essential to revisit new financing instruments, such as eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the single European currency.
Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. President of the Court of Justice, we are facing an unprecedented crisis.

In fact, this was not the time to discuss internally how to organize ourselves. Therefore, my hope is that the Lisbon Treaty will be ratified quickly so that we can face the global scene united and in solidarity as Europeans.

Regarding the economic crisis, in the report I authored and which this Parliament largely approved, it was acknowledged that the recovery plan subsequently presented by the Commission was insufficient.
Today, we are certain that it is not enough.
A crisis that began financially, spills over into the real economy, then employment, and subsequently becomes social.
It is not sufficient and it is blurred.
Every crisis presents an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission to address the real problems of Europeans through serious financial regulation, not the slightest concession.

where possible, as it is currently underway. Not made up of national and individualistic plans, but of a true European initiative. Not through scattered means, but by focusing on the real challenge, which is employment.

In every crisis, there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and Europe to address the real issues faced by European citizens. I hope this will be achieved through a new approach to the recovery plan. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as many members have already done, but particularly on behalf of the Portuguese EPP members, our great satisfaction with the outcome of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe this clearly strengthens the European Union's development and return prospects, creating conditions for a new phase.

We would, of course, like to congratulate all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission present here, as well as, naturally, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union.

played a very important role here, and so we also wish to say with pleasure that, despite all these vicissitudes and while we still await the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked.

We are on the cusp of a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union, and I would like to say that we can also count on another flag from this perspective, which will always be a flag carried by Portuguese MEPs from the EPP: the flag of National Parliaments.
We believe that the Treaty of Lisbon takes a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of National Parliaments into European democracy as well.

And therefore, we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, the representative dimension, and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendum dimension, what is...

The fundamental and essential aspect of democracy is representation, not direct voting. The Treaty of Lisbon is also a significant step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
Therefore, we are very pleased with this decision of the Irish people.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. A brief intervention to welcome the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role played by Fine Gael and its leader and soon-to-be Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, in taking the lead on this process.
a process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became very apparent.
We are them, we are all of us, the primary beneficiaries of the Union's every action.
It is fundamental that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has on our lives on a daily basis.
Europe is our vital space.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, it is good for its citizens.
It is certainly the case with the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can be, simultaneously, a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, having concluded a far too lengthy debate on its organization and functioning, can now focus much more intently, with new and far more effective tools, on the genuine problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth, and employment.
I conclude, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal for future generations.

Considering the information gap regarding the values, competencies, objectives, and mode of operation of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new compulsory subject of European studies.
In an objective, truthful, and concrete manner, European youth will effectively learn about our principles, who we are, what we do, and where we want to go.

It is through the knowledge of these young people that they will come to understand throughout their lives the potential and immense usefulness of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President of the Commission, I begin by congratulating you in this first debate for what this new political control instrument means for the progress and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is European citizens, through their representatives, who stand to benefit.

In light of the most recent developments, the Irish referendum, ratification by Poland, and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I ask what your assessment is of the process for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
there were efforts on the part of the Commission's President
and what is the forecast for an eventual date of entry into force of the Treaty and, on the other hand, to know whether, at this moment and due to this forecast, the Commission

Some treaty transition arrangements have already been made, from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or perhaps it is still in a phase, shall we say, of expectation, therefore, in a wait-and-see phase.

Mr. President of the Commission, having heard that, I would like to know the following. At this stage, when everyone is awaiting the formation of the Commission, fundamentally, what is the perspective that Mr. President holds?

It remains to be seen whether we will now have, until this moment of final ratification by the Czech Republic, a commission in caretaker capacity or whether they will proceed with the appointment procedures for the new commissioners.

Thank you, Mr. President. It is essential that the primary objective of establishing the European External Action Service fulfills the effort of the European institutions, ensuring the creation of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating, and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
It should also represent more than the sum of its parts. It should be an added value compared to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this regard, it seems essential to me that what defines the specificity of the Union should be at the heart of this new reality. And this specificity is the community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Brok report, which advocates and safeguards a close articulation between the Commission and the future Service.

I would like to emphasize two aspects in this regard. The importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure effectiveness and smooth operation.

Lastly, there is a need for an alliance between the Parliament and the Commission to combat the intergovernmental drift that is looming and which could jeopardize the effective functioning of the Service.
The Parliament must, therefore, remain vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a center of excellence, representing the best expertise in foreign policy matters.
Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Commissioner. Firstly, I would like to emphasize the importance of this issue raised by Member Golarensky, as it is a matter of the most fundamental justice.

We all know perfectly well that in a situation of an A flu pandemic, it will be the countries of the South that will suffer the most from this problem and from the consequences of the virus's proliferation, not the countries of the North.

And every year, with total passivity, we witness the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or are treatable in the countries of the North. A vast list includes malaria, dengue, yellow fever, and tuberculosis.
We have no limits for this list and passively witness this issue.

We effectively use the countries of the South as free suppliers of samples of new virus strains so that we can improve treatment in the countries of the North, but we are still left without an effective response to these problems. And therefore, to the questions that have been raised, I would like to add a few more.
We effectively want to address this issue as a public health problem or as a business.
Because if it is a public health issue, we must ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and for that, efforts must be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope this is not the case, whether we are expecting that, after all, vaccine stocks in Europe will become so overcrowded.
that the side effects prove to be so negative in this plan, so that we can then truly have an act of generosity and suddenly start sending the necessary vaccines to the countries of the South.

And lastly, I would just like to ask if the European Union, if we Europeans, if the Commission, feel comfortable with a system or model where Northern countries tackle pandemics through a prevention model, while in Southern countries it is treated as palliative care or merely with what is left over.

Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I would like to express my full support for the issue raised by Mr. Royal and, above all, to highlight the underlying political matter in this subject, which concerns precisely the joint programming of research.

What occurred in terms of joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and, in particular, on Alzheimer's, was that during the process, the rules were changed. We went from having a report to having a resolution, thus eliminating our co-decision-making capacity in this matter. We ceased to be members of parliament and became consultants.
and, therefore, I would like to know whether at least what we recommended will be taken into consideration or not.
The scheduling of investigative activities, regardless of the subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one. In this regard, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they should be scrutinized, that they should be transparent, and that they should be democratic.
What occurred with the process regarding the joint decision and joint planning of the research on Alzheimer's is a process that should not be repeated.

please repeat, and give notice in due time. Therefore, I hope that the last thing that could happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations presented by the Parliament on this matter are not taken into consideration.
In the last month, the regions of Europe were particularly in the spotlight.
The European Week dedicated to regions and cities consolidated the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in the European response to global challenges.
Thus they concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Samezki, and the hundreds of debates that ensued.

Also at a more specific level, the holding of the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the European Union's Ultra-Peripheral Regions, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a milestone in regional policy in favor of European construction.
Global challenges and European responses present an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for the OUTER regions (RUP).

These regions, such as the Azores, beyond the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that offer clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give Europe a distinct advantage in new areas essential to addressing global challenges.

It therefore demands that the President of the Commission clearly put an end to the palace coup that the Commission's non-paper indicates was being prepared, while we, MEPs and European citizens, were advocating the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in defending the cohesion of the European territory.

I would like, first and foremost, to greet the rapporteurs, in particular Mr Martin and also Mr Corbett. As a member of the EPP, I essentially agree with the proposed amendments to the rules of procedure.
I would like to emphasize, essentially, the point that seems to me to be important here and which has not yet been raised this evening, namely the role of National Parliaments.

The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament undoubtedly stems from this Rules of Procedure and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also arises from the connection to National Parliaments.
And what this Regulation, this proposal, now seeks to do is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to strengthen democracy.

on the one hand, the democracy resulting from the instruments of the European Parliament, its oversight mechanisms, its legislative capacity, and, on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of National Parliaments through various instruments.
And so, I find myself, if you will, in complete agreement with the proposals presented.
I disagree with colleague Duff when he suggests that we should postpone the introduction of mechanisms for engagement with National Parliaments.
I believe we can do this right away in light of the Treaty of Lisbon, and this is very important.
I would also like to state that I support the proposal put forward by my colleagues Sayer and Brock concerning representation on the COSAC, and, finally, that I am in agreement.
I am fully in agreement with the observations made here by colleague Brock and other colleagues regarding the primacy of the Parliament and its Members over the Parliament's services.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate the rapporteur for the work done in this report and for her recent intervention.
This new microfinance instrument will enable the provision of microcredit to small businesses and to individuals who have lost their jobs and wish to create their own business and their own job.
This is of great importance during a period in which it is forecasted that the economic crisis will lead to the loss of three and a half million jobs in the European Union alone.

As a result of the economic slowdown, banks have stopped granting loans for job creation and business establishment, and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Well, this new microfinance mechanism will counter this current trend of restricting access to credit, facilitating the acquisition of necessary funds for the launch of new businesses and jobs.
The proposal by the European Commission aims to reallocate 100 million euros from the Progress Programme budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of resources from Progress, which targets the most vulnerable groups, is not by any means the most suitable solution.
For this reason, there is support for the creation of a separate budget line to fund this instrument, as well as an increase in the appropriation to 150 million euros.

We also agree on the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group comprises vulnerable groups who struggle to enter or re-enter the labor market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential for individuals to have financial support and also receive adequate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and the Portuguese EPP Delegation.
Our assessment of the Swedish Presidency is one of nearly absolute success, essentially in four fundamental areas.

The first in the institutional area, the contribution of the Swedish Presidency to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and to the very successful election of the President of the Commission.
For, namely, all ratification issues associated with ratification, was extremely professional and met the standards of what is expected, best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution from the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, naturally, the Commission's work was also immensely important.
We should say that, from my perspective and that of many PPE members, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the most success.
is at the true global frontline of combat, and this is due to the efforts of both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, the Presidency of the Commission.
considers this balance very positive.
A third point is that of financial regulation, which, especially with this last Council, took a step that we consider decisive and which could have a significant impact on exiting the crisis.
And, therefore, I would also like to congratulate you on achieving an agreement in this area.
And finally, I would like to say a word about an area that is of great personal importance to me, namely the Stockholm Programme and, therefore, the field of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that having followed both the Tampere process and, in particular, the subsequent Hague process, I consider this Stockholm program to be absolutely essential. I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt on this.

Thank you, Mr. President. As is known, the recognition of professional qualifications was consolidated into a single legislative act, comprising 15 directives, which gave rise to various practical problems in its application across the different Member States.

The difficulties are well-known, and the Commission should inventory the critical points and conduct an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the implementation of this important internal market provision.
The protectionist measures manifested at various levels constitute an obstacle not only to the free movement of people but also to the internal market.
We should attempt to identify the unclear points to ensure that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by mistrust.
The Union is not asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is a facilitation effort to be made that helps to dismantle professional corporatisms.
An improvement in the application of this directive should involve greater recognition of qualifications through the Solvit network and the EURES network, as well as encouraging...
common platforms, the implementation of effective contact points, and, no less importantly, it should provide for the articulation of this directive with the services directive. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. It is urgent that a debate be promoted on the community budget and on how it can, in the future, contribute to its sustainability and transparency.

The post-2013 financial framework should be built on the principles of solidarity and territorial cohesion, crucial values for regions such as Madeira, which face persistent challenges and therefore require ongoing support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking about and designing cohesion policy.

The Commission has on various occasions referred to certain aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency, and a more results-oriented approach in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues that raise some concerns for me, especially when considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as, for example, value-added sectors.

A realignment such as this could jeopardize Objective 2, which currently benefits around two-thirds of European regions, not to mention potentially being counterproductive in regions with very specific economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that maintaining the criterion of proximity in cohesion policy is vital.

There should continue to be a preference for the allocation and management of structural funds from a regional perspective, rather than a national or even centralized perspective at the European level. Thirdly and finally, but no less importantly, I would like to recall and emphasize Article 349.
349 The Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of the outermost regions regarding access to structural funds, precisely due to their economic and social situation.
Exacerbated by conditionalities and unique, enduring characteristics, these manifest in the aforementioned constant difficulties, thus requiring the claimed permanent aids. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Given the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen were several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than others, but it also created more divisions. As a result, what happened was that we ended up with a situation of every man for himself, where each state can define its own targets and, moreover, on a voluntary basis.
It should be noted that having a target of two degrees Celsius or funding targets with no clarification is of little comfort to us either.
And therefore, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future. And acting in terms of the future means moving from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always aspired to be a leader, and it has consistently affirmed this goal.
but when we reached Copenhagen, it ended up hesitating, neither setting nor defending the targets it had previously stated as its own and which it would not implement.

And, therefore, what I ask is whether in the future we will be more just, whether we will continue to allow, at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest to continue paying the heaviest price.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to draw attention here to what is happening in Portugal at this very moment, where it is clear that the mass media
brought to light a government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which jeopardizes freedom of expression.
Just this week, a well-known journalist, Mário Crespo, had one of his columns censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the Prime Minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates must provide substantial explanations to the country; he must clarify that he is not suppressing, restricting, or censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

In the way we are going, Portugal is no longer a state of law, it is a state of formal law, where the Prime Minister limits himself to formalities, procedures, and formalisms, and does not want to provide substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we envision a substantive State of Law.

Many thanks, Mr. President. The Green Paper on the Reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, for which my colleague from the Azores, Maria do Séu Patrão Neves, is the rapporteur, presents a unique opportunity for debate on a sector of great significance to the local development balance of the outermost regions.

Madera follows the ongoing discussion with particular interest and deems it imperative to propose a differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from distinct fishing regimes.
It is fundamental to advocate for a principle of positive discrimination regarding the restriction of access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone solely to local artisanal fleets.
In Madeira, priority is given to supporting the modernization of vessels and to management strategies that ensure the conservation of a comprehensive group of species in the long term.
Only in this way will we be able to prevent unsustainable situations for economic, environmental, and social balance.
Lastly, we will advocate for fisheries in the outermost regions to have permanent and non-time-limited support.
This report concerning the ERDF aims to extend the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support was only applicable to marginalized communities residing in urban areas of the new Member States.
In other words, since the vast majority of these types of communities live in rural areas and shelters, they could not benefit from support to replace poor-quality housing.
Ultimately, it is a matter of filling a gap and providing Member States and their regions with greater opportunities in the policy aimed at mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
Health also entails equal treatment for all Member States, as marginalized communities with support and integration needs deserve our attention, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

Upon concluding the first reading of this significant report in the fight against poverty and for human dignity, its rapid implementation within the framework of the economic recovery plan is also achieved, providing a swift response to the crisis that affects us.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. Allow me to begin by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr. Van Nistelrooy, for his efforts in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the willingness he has always shown to incorporate other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on amendments to the FEDER Regulation that are of particular importance to the so-called old Member States and also to Portugal.

These changes will enable the extension of ESF (European Social Fund) usage in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities, as currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development projects.

The amendments I proposed, along with other colleagues, and which were approved by a large majority in the Committee on Regional Development, will enable the former Member States, not just the new ones as originally proposed, to also benefit from this funding opportunity.
With this, I attempted to prevent the setting of a dangerous precedent that would exclude all former Member States from this and likely other additional uses of Community aid.
This would make no sense, as housing-related issues, particularly among marginalized communities, exist in both new and old Member States.

I take this opportunity to reiterate that the length of membership in the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds, and that this criterion should be categorically abandoned.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, with a view to territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding, rather than punishing, regions that have proven exemplary in the use of Community aid.

At this moment, I would like to primarily underscore to the Commission and the President of the Commission the manner in which they have worked with this Parliament over these past months of the investiture process.

There is no organ in the world with executive capacity and legislative initiative that is subject to the presentation by its President of a program before the Parliament, to a hearing with all groups.

parliamentarians, to a vote by an absolute and expressive majority, to bring all the commissioners here to be heard one by one with their own program, with 3 to 4 hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.

There is someone who has agreed to negotiate with the Parliament a framework agreement in which they have, first and foremost, agreed to justify and enhance the powers of the Parliament within the scope of the legislative initiative.

which accepted the principle of full access to information, whether in legislative and political action or in international negotiations, which accepted taking into account the Parliament's opinion on the Commissioners, on the reshuffling of the Commissioners.
This means, once and for all, and from my point of view, that the Commission has demonstrated from July until now that it is willing to have a close relationship with the Parliament.

Doing so clearly, evidently, and unequivocally demonstrated that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the community method referred to by colleague Sariusz Wolski is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, the Commission and the Framework Agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Mr. President, five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to view this period as a missed opportunity.
And the blame is not solely on their political elites.
It is certain that these powers have been excessively consumed by wars of power and influence.
that many reforms were left unfulfilled, many never went beyond the paper.
It is unconscionable that, in any democracy, electoral laws should be changed between the two rounds of an election.
does not dignify those who proposed them, those who voted for them, or those who promulgated them.
and translate the little commendable and recommendable intentions in your agenda.
There is much to be changed under the lack of independence of the Judiciary, subject to excessive influence not only from political power but also from economic agents.
Without a free and independent justice system, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, and there is no progress.
But the blame for this disenchantment also lies heavily with this Parliament and, essentially, with many Member States.
I would like us to, for a few seconds, put ourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to the vicissitudes of history, is still not a member of the European Union.
What would we expect from the Union?
solidarity.
