But many foreign ministries, solely concerned with not upsetting or offending Moscow, have exploited and taken advantage of the ongoing internal struggles in Kiev to avoid unequivocally stating that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if this is the freely expressed majority will of its people and provided that they meet the established criteria, Ukraine may aspire to become a member of the European Union in the future.
I would like to emphasize that in insular regions, air transport is sometimes the only means of access, and operational conditions are influenced by the size of their passenger and cargo flows.

If there are insular regions where the abundance of these air routes is common to many airlines, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibility, there are others like the Azores, where these routes are still limited, failing to attract the interest of operators.

As a result, airfares are higher, constituting a barrier to population mobility and a challenge in attracting tourists that would allow the enormous potential for development and diversification of their economic base to flourish and consolidate.
This situation is particularly detrimental during times of crisis such as the one we are facing.

It is therefore fundamental to provide temporary support that encourages increased flows to enable the market to function, also sharing these regions of high tourist potential in the objectives of the trans-European networks in bringing Europe's peripheries closer together.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I rise today in this Chamber, my voice choked with consternation, having personally lived through and witnessed the tragedy that struck Madeira last Saturday.

My words are, obviously, to associate myself with the feeling of pain and mourning that has affected the families of the deceased victims, who now number 42, to whom I pay my respects and express my condolences for their losses.

The true extent of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed, as search and rescue teams, who have been working tirelessly since Saturday in a Herculean effort that I commend, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
And there is concern that the number of victims may increase.

The scenario is one of large-scale destruction, with significant material damage to access roads, highways, and entirely devastated key points, as well as essential services such as water and electricity supply.
There are approximately 600 displaced people who have lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal course of life.
But now it is necessary to look ahead.
It is also necessary to give people a message of solidarity, hope, and trust.

It is necessary to provide assistance. It is in this chapter that the European Union and Parliament, in particular, have a role to play. They are crucial in the process of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we must do so swiftly, because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us the most.

I appeal here to the Commission and its President, José Manuel Durão Barroso, in particular to the Commissioner for Regional Development and Hannes Swoboda, and I welcome their initiative to visit Madeira at the earliest opportunity.
asking him to also be a bearer of this message of hope, of aid, and of support for reconstruction. Because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately, once again, has taken from us.
But I am certain that we will, because as the Madeira anthem taught me, the people of Madeira are humble, stoic, and brave.
It is the people who, between the rocks, carried the earth, heroes of labor on Mount Agreste.
Through wood, it will honor its history and, through the path of labor, it will struggle and achieve its well-being and glory.
We commence this plenary session today with a moment of silence.

And it was a minute of silence with two meanings: one of solidarity with the victims of this catastrophe that struck Madeira and their families, and a tribute to all the workers who have been providing assistance to these victims tirelessly.
But a minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that goes beyond the one we are making here.
What we saw in Madeira is a phenomenon that will increasingly repeat itself.
Climate change causes extreme phenomena to recur, and we need to have responses to them.
We cannot prevent natural disasters, but neither should we be condemned to always experience their effects as dramatically on people's lives.
That is why we must advocate for planning and development policies that are guided towards the public good.

But I would like to conclude, Mr. President, with what is most important and what brought us here: the European Commission, the European Parliament, and the European institutions must have the capacity to provide an urgent response to an emergency situation. And for this, the necessary financial resources and the requisite speed are required.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of the tragic events of Saturday on the Island of Madeira.

As a Sassone, as a Portuguese citizen, and as a European, I cannot fail to appeal to the Parliament and the Union to demonstrate active solidarity with the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its people.
It is in the regions where the presence of the Union needs to be felt, and it is precisely in these moments when its solidarity is most necessary that it is also most important for it to make sense.

Mr. President, I too wish to express my solidarity with the people of Madeira in their time of grief and to urge the European institutions, and the Commission in particular, to unlock all available resources, all means at their disposal, to provide the necessary aid.
I would also like to emphasize that, when a disaster of this kind occurs, it is much more difficult to address its consequences when it happens in poor countries and poor regions.

However, in the case of Madeira, we must also consider that the island's economic base is directly affected by the fact that, being dependent on tourism, it suffers a double blow when its natural beauties, accessibility, and quality of life are all destroyed.

Therefore, there is indeed a distinct situation when we encounter problems of this severity in poor countries and poor regions, and particularly in mountainous and tourist areas, as is the case with Madeira.
It is therefore absolutely essential that all the adaptations that have been foreseen, requested, and recalled here with regard to the Solidarity Fund not be delayed any further.

that they immediately take effect, because due to climate change, these processes, unfortunately, will repeat, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those experiencing torrential regimes in terms of water and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you very much once again, Mr. President.
Commissioner and Council, we are here discussing the reinvention of the energy system at European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I believe it is one of the very important challenges, as indeed mentioned in the communication that is presented.
And it is one of the challenges we must address head-on. But there is no clarification here, hence the importance of raising these issues and requesting clarification.
It seems that not only is there a lack of clarification regarding funding, but there is also a lack of political clarification.
There is talk of energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear power, biofuels, solar energy, and indeed, energy efficiency is discussed as a cheaper way to reduce emissions.
It astonishes me that there are much cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that are not even mentioned in this communication, such as, for example, immediately reducing consumption.
energetic, microgeneration, distribution, and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to go solely through large structures and energy access.
I believe that in this way we would certainly be contributing to greater financial clarity to make the plan more affordable.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, there is still a lack of discussion on what seems to me to be an absolutely crucial point: the persistent emphasis placed on public-private partnerships as if they were a solution for everything.
When asked where the money comes from, the Commission tells us it comes from where it is.
I must admit that I am no more enlightened by being told that the money will come from where it is without being precisely informed of its exact location.

And therefore, this reliance on public-private partnerships, which is systematically employed when discussing low-carbon technologies, leaves us with one certainty. Not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that they are public or private partnerships, we know upfront who will be paying.
Those who will pay are the taxpayers initially, they are the consumers who, by chance, are also taxpayers in the end.
And we know that, initially, those who pay less are the private institutions and organizations, which make the investment, are remunerated for it, but in the end they end up monopolizing the profits.
And without this clarification, it seems to me that, once again, we are systematically passing on to future generations the bill for the change in the European energy model.

Thank you, Madam President. The European Union has recently concluded an agreement within the World Trade Organization with the countries of Latin America, in which it undertook to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana imports from these countries.

I draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement will have direct negative effects on European banana producers, specifically on banana producers in Madeira, Portugal, but also, even more intensely, on those in the Canary Islands, Spain.

I reiterate that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously hampered by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their holdings, which forces them to confront permanent difficulties that hinder their development.

It is, therefore, urgent to take measures to protect banana, timber, and Canary Islands producers, given the severe and immediate impact the new Geneva Agreement will have on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas from these ultra-peripheral regions.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, as the draftsperson of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to begin by...
Congratulate Deputy Krielov, even in his forced absence, and emphasize the way he was able to elaborate this important report, facilitating the main objective.
I would also like to congratulate Deputy Creel for the presentation she gave us.
This primary objective is, in short, to simplify procedures and expedite the implementation of programs funded by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds, and the Regional Development Fund.
In the context of the current financial, economic, and social crisis, pressure on national financial resources has been mounting.
This pressure will lessen with a better use of community funding, with the faster arrival of these resources to those most affected by the economic downturn.
Over 20 million Europeans are unemployed, which is 4 million more than a year ago, and unfortunately, the trend is rising.

This situation requires ensuring the effective implementation of cohesion programs, as they represent the most powerful and relevant lever for aiding the real economy, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the driving force of the European economy and the agents of sustainable growth, generating both quantity and quality in terms of jobs.

The continued simplification and clarification of the rules governing cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the implementation rate of the programs, especially since it will already

national, regional, and local authorities the possibility of relying on clearer and less bureaucratic rules, which will enable greater flexibility in adapting programs to new challenges. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Of course, this crisis was an unforeseen crisis, and clearly, the precautionary principle had to take priority.
but there are lessons to be learned, and the first is that, for five days, no European voice was heard that was politically strong and responsible enough.
And this voice was missed in terms of defending passenger interests, clarifying their rights, seeking transportation alternatives, and coordinating solutions.

A second conclusion is that the exit from the crisis cannot appear, in the eyes of the common citizen, to be a game of power dynamics between those who seek to avoid losses and those who wish to uphold the principle of precaution.
There must be clear transparency and clear objectivity regarding the conditions under which one exits a situation of complete closure of the European space.
And, therefore, the improvement of scientific testing and coordination at the level...

Thank you, Mr. President. I would also like to begin by commending the work and persistence of colleague Tikal on this important dossier and for her efforts in improving energy performance in buildings and contributing to a more sustainable Europe.
Energy expenditure in the European Union, as we know, is far above acceptable levels, which is why progressing with proposals of this nature is so crucial.
It is high time we had an ambitious policy at European level and added to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation we are living through.
The construction sector is cited as one of the sectors, one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of energy economics, but it is not just that.
And it is not just that, which is why it is an area par excellence for the affirmation of public policies. And it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.
We must, therefore, seize this opportunity presented by investments in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and their potential for creating millions of jobs in the coming years.
It is not only about new buildings, but also the rehabilitation and restoration of existing structures that are degraded or no longer suitable.

Let us, therefore, take advantage of this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revival of the European economy. We cannot continue to squander the investment that can and should be strategic for recovery from the crisis. Let us hope that the Commission will invest and that the Member States will know how to make the most of this investment. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to begin by congratulating Mr. Manders on the work done in this report and also thanking the colleagues who collaborated with him on this file.

In fact, the mere fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the existing regulatory framework, by consolidating all existing legislation, three core directives on the denomination and labeling of textile products, into a single regulation, is in itself a significant achievement.

Moreover, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities, and it will also enable the integration of newly developed fibers, thereby fostering innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This revision will also enhance the transparency of the process for adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fiber names.
It seems there is no doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
Let's see, the textile industry will benefit from administrative cost savings and the ability to market new fibers earlier.
For their part, the authorities of the Member States will not need to transpose the changes into national legislation, which will enable a significant cost saving for these Member States.
And consumers will have the guarantee that the fibers denoted meet specific characteristics, also benefiting from the fact that new fibers reach the market earlier.
For the European industry, the introduction of these new fibers is important as a means of promoting innovation, also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
In the current context of a globalized world, emerging economies feature ever-expanding markets where millions of products circulate, manufactured by countless companies.
The focus on innovation and the speed at which this innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this regulation may see its competitiveness increased.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will undoubtedly gain market share with this new regulation and, in doing so, contribute to increased employment in Europe.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner. The shortage of organs for transplantation is a major problem.

has been mentioned here several times, and it is a larger problem that raises questions both in terms of public health and associated issues such as the strengthening of the black market and organ trafficking, which in no way enhances our health systems or our citizens.

Therefore, we must combat this crime and do so through legislative proposals such as the ones we are discussing here. It seems to me that this is more than important and more than relevant, and so I wish to focus on the most significant dimensions and issues raised by these two proposals.
because the system we have so far, without these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
inequalities between Member States, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities in access to bodies, inequalities among citizens that, in my view, we cannot afford.
Therefore, it is important to emphasize that these inequalities must be reduced. And these proposals aim to address precisely that.
I believe that a European system that still retains certain specificities of some of the countries, so that they are not compelled to have more restrictive systems, is the answer to this problem.
And the work carried out by the rapporteurs, Mr. Mikolasik, and Mr. Perello Rodrigues, is of utmost importance and contributes significantly to addressing the problem we face.
If we are talking about proposals that are based on and supported by issues such as donation, volunteering, free-of-charge services, confidentiality, and data protection,

traceability, responsibility, and here I believe it is important, from the Parliament's perspective, to go as far as the patient's recovery, not just donation, and cooperation among Member States. I believe we are on the right track.
I must only mention, however, and regarding the notions among the living, I am pleased by the inclusion and expansion, this expansion achieved with rights.

Obviously ensuring all rights and all conditions, but it is very important that we have gone beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be just another way of having other forms of equality.

Therefore, promoting data as the main focus for transplants and safeguarding data and patient security seem to me more than sufficient reasons for us all to come together tomorrow and vote in favor of these two proposals, which are of utmost importance to the European Union.

President, Minister, and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with organs from another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals differences, showing that medium-sized countries like Portugal perform very well in such comparisons, and larger countries like Spain are now recognized as organizational and best-practice leaders.
some principles and practices to safeguard.
Firstly, strengthening scientific knowledge and information to increasingly encourage living donors and promote post-mortem donation. Secondly, prohibiting the commercialization of...

gift, not only within Member States but also outside them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, the proactive promotion of donation in hospitals as a way to overcome scarcity.

Finally, Madam President, ensure equal access to transplantation for all those in need and who qualify according to harmonized clinical criteria, adhering to the principle of universality of access to health, a paradigm of the social Europe of which we are proud.
I congratulate the rapporteurs on the work accomplished.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great, let's say, satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese members of the European Party
European, this process of accession, of the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, is now commencing.

We, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal as early as 1761, and pioneering in the abolition of the death penalty, can only be, evidently, interested and supportive of this accession process.

I would like to draw attention, however, to the fact that we consider it highly important for the European Parliament to closely monitor every step of the negotiation process for the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider this aspect, from a technical, legal, and political standpoint, to be fundamental because the Parliament is also a House of Human Rights and a place where human rights hold great significance. And I would now like to emphasize what we consider to be very important.

For us, members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important, it is a very good signal that we send to the members of the Council of Europe, of the European Union's accession, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, it is a sign of the European Union's strengthened commitment to its situation and to the levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.

Madam President and Mr. Commissioner, social housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities for the benefit of society as a whole.
According to Protocol 26 annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon, it is the responsibility of national, regional, and local authorities to implement and organize this type of service.
Hence, it is somewhat incomprehensible that the target audience is restricted to families with incomes below 33,000 euros.
This is a measurement of poverty that is made in absolute and purely financial terms, without considering the diversity of the 27 Member States, reducing itself to a simple argument of solvency.
Now, social housing addresses cultural, social, and proximity-to-workplace issues, the significant redefinition of women's roles in the market, and the mobility of workers within the European space.
The struggle the European Union is waging to emerge from the current crisis revolves around economic growth, which in turn drives an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
economic and cultural reasons and the need for their integration, even with the risks of ghettoization that they entail, which we must combat with a fair balance.
Is the Commission not encroaching on the realm of the Member States' competencies?

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, allow me, Madam President, to highlight the fact that we are discussing the first report from the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative procedure provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon.

This is a historic moment that, by confirming to this House the voting intention I propose, will mark the best possible start to this new period of shared competences in agricultural matters within the European Union.
I am specifically co-legislating on your ultra-peripheral regions, providing a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union that is strengthened by cohesion.
In the spirit of active solidarity, with respect for the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path for the construction of our common European project.

I also speak about introducing fundamental regulations to ensure the viability of the already century-old sugar industry in the Azores, the region from which I hail, and thus I particularly rejoice, contributing to a...
healthy agricultural diversification in a region where, as we know, the dairy sector holds a unique, irreplaceable dimension at the national level, which we must sustain and consolidate.
Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Ciolos and the senior Commission officials with whom we have worked and negotiated for the openness and flexibility they have demonstrated.
The Spanish presidency of the Council also exerted boundless efforts to ensure that our shared will to reach an agreement at first reading became a reality.

This acknowledgment, obviously, extends to the Shadow rapporteurs from the other political groups, as well as to the excellent staff of the Secretariat of the Agriculture Committee of this Parliament. Their collaboration enabled us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would like to underscore as well the decisive contribution made by the Agricultural Federation of the Azores and by the regional and national governments in the way they engaged and committed to finding a solution for Azorean sugar.

The presentation of the Council's proposed regulation on October 2nd to the Agriculture Committee took place at a time when there were no prospects for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which was still awaiting ratification by all Member States.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal should be adopted through a simplified procedure, without any amendments, to take effect from 1 January 2010.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and despite the prevailing opinion at the time from other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, that the proposal should continue under the simplified procedure, as they believed that...

The proposal did not require amendments and should enter into force swiftly. Despite holding this view, I and the Socialist and Democrat Group believe that the Parliament should already speak out under the Lisbon Treaty, assuming its role as co-legislator.

We did so in good time, for from then on new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Committee and the opinion of colleague Nunta Cheira, whom I take this opportunity to...

I would like to express my congratulations and gratitude for the cooperation always extended throughout this process, and now with my report introducing new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as with the contribution and support of my colleagues on the Agriculture Committee.

I would like to conclude this initial intervention by stating that, regarding the amendments proposed by the REGI Committee and voted on in the AGRIC Committee, which I supported, we were unable to secure acceptance of the compromise reached in the trilogue.

It was essential to secure an agreement at first reading, thereby preserving the improvements already achieved and the need for entry into force to ensure its retroactive effect from January of this year was not compromised.
However, as the Commission is already preparing a review document for POSEI, we will undoubtedly have the opportunity to discuss it again soon.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. We are facing an acceleration of a global shift that has devastating consequences for our economic, political, and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.
We are witnessing an unprecedented weakening of the capacity of states to respond.
The European Union must, consequently, identify common causes and allies and act clearly and unitedly on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require lucid joint action.

If we do not take the necessary collective measures of rigor and accountability, Europe will be relegated to marginalization and impoverishment. Only a strong Europe, respectful of its common rules, can provide an adequate response to the new times.
Fragile and indebted states lack the capacity to protect their citizens.
Consequently, we need to be able to regain citizens' trust, win the battles for stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, Monetary Union stability, globalization, and strategic choices.
This, under the penalty of having our future compromised.
And we win the future by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, and building a new model based on the values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the Europe 2020 Strategy and the integrated guidelines constitute essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For proper implementation and achievement, it is necessary to establish clear and quantifiable objectives in employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also decisive for the success of the strategy that everything be done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the proper implementation of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the Economic and Monetary Union celebrated its 10th anniversary, the Commission regarded the euro as the Union's most successful project.
Today, we would find it difficult to assert this without qualifications, because the crisis has clearly shown that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
Minimum salvation measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let us not be mistaken. The pressure conditions, the direct interests of the main players.
member countries. The painful nature of the decisions, their slowness, has weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and the world.
It is necessary to confront the facts.
The European Union and the euro are an integration process, not merely a cooperation among countries.
are an unfinished process that at this moment either strengthens or runs a very high risk of disappearing.
There are three themes that need to be addressed. Firstly, it is important to consolidate the instruments that have been implemented in this emergency context. A monetary fund needs to be created.
In Europe, it is necessary to move forward with Eurobonds, to develop the European supervisory and regulatory architecture, and to establish a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second dimension, it is important to realize that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The 1% growth forecast for the European Union is unsustainable in terms...
whether in terms of its demographic composition or in terms of unemployment reduction. The Europe 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a set of good ideas without the means to implement them.

Third dimension, Mr. Commissioner Lirenne, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences among the Member States that make up the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues from the EPP group here have already painted a very comprehensive picture of the situation.
I deem it necessary to make a reference to the role of nation-states at this juncture.
In fact, national governments also have a role to play in imposing these requirements within their own states.
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and this project of monetary and economic integration to be taken forward.
And here I would like to say that our party, the party affiliated with the EPP, which is the PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in its austerity measures, because we consider

that the mistakes that, over these fifteen years, the socialist government has made in Portugal and that today, unfortunately, are evident to all, that these mistakes need to be rectified and will have the support of the PSD to be corrected.

But we are supporting the austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government, and it is a good example for other similar cases because it is not reducing expenditure. And what is fundamental is not just...

increase taxes to reduce the deficit, but it is about cutting spending, it is about demanding that the government have the courage to take measures that reduce spending, that alleviate the deficit, that ease public debt.
This holds true for Portugal and applies to other states that are currently in a difficult situation. And we, as European parliamentarians, have the responsibility to also act in our own countries.
a defense of the necessary measures to ensure that the euro emerges stronger and that this integration space and this dream, which is a dream of the EPP and a dream of ours, can be realized.
Therefore, we criticize those governments that do not have the courage to take the necessary measures within their own states.

Dear colleagues, I would like to begin by stating that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006-2010 roadmap for equality between men and women, and which aims to influence the strategy on this matter for the future, could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less controversial.

In fact, the approach to various ethically sensitive issues, particularly the matter of women's sexual and reproductive health, should have been different if the goal was truly to achieve the broadest possible consensus.

With this in mind, I would like to emphasize that in so-called normal economic growth times, there is great concern for women's rights, particularly regarding the disparity between the situation of men and women in the workplace, in society, and in the family. However, these issues are deeply exacerbated by the economic and social crisis we are experiencing.
Hence the need for a reinforced strategic commitment from Member States, at the level of local and regional entities and community institutions, regarding protection.

To say, in line with what President Dole and colleague Werner Langen stated, it is crucial that there be an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government be centered around the Commission.
This is the first point I wanted to emphasize. And having said that, it is not just, as we have done here this entire morning, to focus our debate on immediate issues, but...
also in those included in the Europe 2020 Strategy. And I would underline, in particular, the issue of education and training for the young, the issue of innovation, research and development.

because it is in these niches that Europe will be able to compete in the global arena. And today, I must unfortunately say that the European educational model has failed, and it has failed because when compared to the model of emerging countries,

like India, like China, like Brazil, is today a less demanding and less rigorous model. Therefore, I also ask that in the audacity of this idea of innovation, development, research, and education, there be rigor and exigency within the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and high standards will we prepare our youth to compete in the global market.

We cannot merely think about the crisis of this year or the next two or three years; we must consider the strategy for Europe over the next 10 to 20 years, which hinges on a rigorous and demanding educational system.
Mr. Commissioner, never before has the European project, built with so much effort over the past 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is immense. The financial system, which was supposed to serve them, has destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.

Regarding the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market, including banking, insurance, and securities, the way forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing here today.
We indeed need a strong European supervisory architecture, covering all products and actors, equipped with methodologies and tools for...
effective interventions and be able to respond to the reality of a market that, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spills over into the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms in place that limit contagion, especially regarding the banking system, as it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the custodian of citizens' savings.

Here, precisely within the powers and competencies of the Banking Authority, lies the ability to implement a new strategy on the management of cross-border crises in the banking sector, the subject to which my report refers.
It is not in our power to prevent bank failures, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is carried out in a manner that...
in an orderly manner, limiting the collateral effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from bearing the costs of the crises they generate.

For this, a set of new tools is required. It is necessary to adopt common rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology for all parties involved in restructuring, reorganization, or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, particularly bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to grant supervisors extended powers of intervention.
It is necessary to develop clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that enable interventions to be initiated in a struggling institution.
It is necessary to prepare contingency plans.
This entire process, for 27 member states, requires time.
However, around 50 banks out of the 12,000 operating in Europe account for 70% of the assets.
Now, this means an enormous concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene prioritarily on them.

There are, therefore, conditions to propose a special and urgent process for the resolution of banks, which, being cross-border in nature and due to their size and relationships with other banks, may have a systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European Banking Authority, although operating within the College of National Supervisors.
It is both possible and urgent that, due to the risk they pose, they start contributing to a fund that finances potential interventions.
it is necessary and important that the Banking Authority establish a specialized unit to coordinate interventions in the event of difficulties in these banks.
In aggregate, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in systemic transnational banks are consistent and coherent, and between them,
different countries and, above all, that a principle so cherished in Europe be upheld, namely, that the costs of pollution caused by these banks be borne by the polluter themselves.

This proposal fits perfectly within the context of our discussion, particularly regarding the competencies of the Banking Authority. Indeed, it could be argued that it represents the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee, there was an overwhelming majority in support of this proposal, with 87% of the votes.
We also count here in the plenary on the massive vote of this institution, in order to, by massively supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic, we...
Let us take urgent and necessary action to rekindle the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system, and particularly in the banking system. Thank you very much.
Thank you. Briefly, to emphasize just four points.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the planet's main environmental and social problems, and each year we lose 13 million hectares of forest. This contributes to 20% of the world's carbon emissions and poses a massive threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is incalculable and, as such, is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and floods, or even the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Forest loss puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact is not evenly shared among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those that most depend on forests and nature for their survival are the most affected.
Deforestation pertains to our collective existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and social justice.
The primary cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which accounts for 20% to 40% of the world's industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also discussing the transfer of wealth from producer countries to consumer countries of the same timber.
This illegal practice endangers the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that engage in it.
Pretty words are not enough.
This Parliament must adopt strong and consequential measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in this direction by defining the ban on timber trade.
Good intentions alone are not enough.
Effective means are required, namely sanctions which, in this case, may be of three types.

First, fines that effectively remove the economic benefit from illegal practices, increased in the event of recidivism. Second, confiscation of the wood from the products in question. And third, immediate suspension of the authorization to engage in commercial activity.

And so it is because those who exploit or trade in a natural resource must be socially responsible. And so it is also because those who first place wood or wood products in the European Union must be required to take due diligence to ensure that it is legally harvested wood.
That is why all subsequent operators must provide basic information about this wood, namely its provenance and its destination.
The population should also have the right, and I conclude here, Mr. President, the right to access information about who complies and who does not comply. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Europe needs to renew its confidence and hope.
In a crisis that has not yet been overcome, we had the firefighters, as Jacques Delors said.
We hope that the Belgian Presidency will bring the architects.
The first test, of course, will be, as early as September, the Council's approach to the Parliament's proposals regarding the financial architecture.

But today, one of the greatest European challenges is to ensure that the European currency does not collapse, whether due to a lack of monitoring instruments, the absence of growth in the eurozone, or, above all, the growing internal divergences and tensions caused within the economies that comprise it.

Cutting structural funds today, as the Commission proposes, funds that were created to stimulate convergence for diverging economies, seems to be putting firefighters in charge of fanning the flames of a fire that has not yet been extinguished.
We clearly need architects.
A final point, I would like to know the external dimension of the European Union's action, in particular, to learn a little more about what the Belgian Presidency proposes for Cancún and Doha.

Thank you, Mr. President. As agricultural policies become increasingly market-oriented, farmers in Europe face very low income levels, and millions of consumers, as a result of the crisis that affects everyone, are in urgent need of keeping food prices affordable.

That is why if farmers' incomes are going to depend increasingly on the values generated in markets and the price of food on their proper functioning, then improving the operation of the food supply chain...
It becomes absolutely necessary for a more equitable distribution of the value generated, from agricultural producers to end consumers, ensuring fair incomes for some and adequate prices for others.

To achieve this, it is necessary to rebalance the relationships established throughout the food supply chain, to make them transparent, and to ensure the existence of a framework of fair and competitive good practices.
In this regard, we call on the Commission to take into account the widely supported proposals in the Committee on Agriculture.
A few days ago, in Aroca, Portugal, all the workers at a footwear company were dismissed via a simple text message, without further explanation.

The environmental catastrophe currently under discussion, although occurring outside the geographical space of the Union, concerns all of us, European citizens.

The notion of sustainable development that we believe in is a concept that transcends administrative boundaries and religious creeds, viewing the planet as a whole rather than as the sum of its parts.
The Jordan River is, therefore, a problem for all of humanity and not just for the populations or communities directly affected by the scarcity or poor quality of its water.
Water. Think globally, act locally, common sense tells us.
That is what we are doing here today, thinking globally.
As the European Union, we should assist in local actions to mitigate and reverse the ongoing degradation of the flow and water quality of the Jordan River.
And to act or help act, the Union already has a legislative, institutional framework and instruments at its disposal.
I refer to the Union for the Mediterranean, its Secretariat, and FEMIP, managed by the European Investment Bank.
This is, obviously, a topic that the Delegation of this Parliament, which I chair, on relations with the countries of the Mashriq, will follow closely.

It is obvious that the action leading to the resolution of this environmental tragedy should, first and foremost, be undertaken by the states and local authorities whose populations directly benefit from it.
In this context, I would like to emphasize two ideas present in the Resolution.
Firstly, the establishment of a commission for the management of the entire Jordan River basin, comprised of representatives from the states or authorities that utilize these waters.
And here Europe can help, by sharing, for example, the experience of the International Commission for the Protection of the Rhine River.
Secondly, the support and dissemination of good practices regarding joint community projects, involving Jordanian, Israeli, and Palestinian citizens,
namely those promoted by Friends of the Earth Middle East, which Ross's colleague just mentioned, regarding the efficient and proper management of the water resources in the Jordan Valley basin.
Finally, Mr. President, and on an even broader scale, emphasize the example of cooperation and peaceful coexistence that this endeavor represents.

At this moment, while regretting the absence of the European Union from the process, we welcome and encourage the resumption of the new direct dialogue process between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. We wish to commend this direct engagement between the two parties.

and which defends the interests of European citizens. And my hope is that the remaining agenda follows the same methodology and that we achieve the same success.

Thank you, Madam President. Here today we discuss yet another situation of human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of Syrian activist Aytan Al-Malé, an 80-year-old lawyer, accused of allegedly spreading false, exaggerated news that weakens his country's national sentiments.

In addition to violating numerous treaties and international conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country's own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction over civilians.

The decision that was made regarding this man and regarding other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various arrests, the restrictions on freedom of movement, and the arbitrary measures taken against this individual,
by the Syrian authorities are practices that contradict Syria's important role in the entire region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in this country to improve the social situation.
I repeat, today we are discussing yet another situation of human rights violation.
It is not possible to isolate it from the various discussions we had here this week.
I highlight two. The first, the rejection of the death sentence by stoning imposed on Sakineh Ashtiani.
many voices united and there have already been some results.

It is not yet time to sing victory, but even less so is it time for us to remain silent. Today, we approved a significant resolution against the abuses imposed by Sarkozy's government on Romanian and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights knows no borders and is not a struggle that can be waged solely beyond our shores.
Today we set a good example of how struggles also occur behind closed doors.
The unjustifiable imprisonment of Aitán Al-Malé unites us all here today.
She is a human rights advocate.
Human rights defenders must be free individuals, and this is what we demand of the Syrian authorities.
We, too, as human rights defenders, will not leave you alone. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the growing trend for the safety profile of new medicines to only be fully understood after their market entry necessitates a more effective pharmacovigilance system than has been in place hitherto.
We are faced with a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level. We have brought it closer to citizens. Now,
Over the past few decades, new medications have played a crucial role in public health and healthcare advancements.
Adverse reactions caused by medications continue to be, however, the fifth leading cause of hospital death.
The proposals presented strengthen the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community pharmacovigilance system, enhancing coordination and transparency.
aims at monitoring, early detection, communication, and assessment of adverse reactions.
The new medications will have a graphic symbol indicating that they are still under scrutiny.

User participation in control is encouraged, national-level efficacy studies are promoted, a new awareness of environmental consequences is fostered, and community control institutions, such as the PRAC, are refined.

and, therefore, with the proposals presented in this legislative package, welcoming the final document to be voted on tomorrow. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr. President, I would like to begin by expressing my gratitude and congratulations to the rapporteur, as well as to all the colleagues who were involved in this process.
We know that adverse drug effects are the fifth leading cause of hospital deaths, a fact that bears repeating, and a robust and transparent drug surveillance system is crucial.
We now have the opportunity to enhance the safety of medications that are already available, going beyond laboratory tests which do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were needed to justify the importance of a new system, consider what happened with the H1N1 flu vaccine. There was haste in bringing the vaccine to market and negligence in investigating the side effects that were detected and which still delay a complete inquiry.
That is why it is necessary for us to continue deepening this path.
This directive ensures the more active involvement of healthcare professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.
Indeed, cooperation between countries and the Union can be a positive-sum game.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, a Europe without economic, social, and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands, and areas with low population density face particularly challenging obstacles that must be overcome in the name of a Europe of the peoples.
But we must go beyond declarations of intent, otherwise, we have the reverse effect, that is, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are vast reservoirs of significant resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands, and green areas provide an essential service to all, yet they face constraints that limit their economic potential.
to reciprocate.
The populations of these regions should be supported in a spirit of solidarity by all.
Submit your proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and to development.
Many of these regions are authentic outdoor laboratories, given their wealth, but do not have equal access to resources for research.
Why not, then, endow them with centers of excellence in research, creating quality jobs and dynamizing their economies?
A second proposal pertains to energy.
These regions can and should serve as embryos for projects that demonstrate the potential of energy self-sufficiency and sustainability, particularly through microgeneration from local sources.
reducing dependency, increasing equality, and creating jobs.
Lastly, I wish to point out that using GDP as the sole or primary indicator for the allocation of funds and aid can only lead to further injustice.
It is therefore very important to use supplementary data, particularly those that depict the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot fail to make special mention here of the peoples of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous regions, and the depopulated interior areas of Portugal.
Through their efforts, they contribute greatly to the development and to the quality of life of all Europeans.
These and all regions have their own context.
Social, economic, and territorial cohesion should not be viewed as a charitable service.
This is where we define whether or not we want a true European redistribution policy.
I consider, for all these reasons, this resolution as an important, but first step. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the goal of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities between the various regions.
It is not enough, however, to express the objectives to be achieved in the text of the treaties.
There are regions within the Union that face permanent constraints which significantly condition their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to implement specific programs that effectively and realistically overcome the delay of these regions by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources, and contributing to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 Strategy.

This incentive to these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments, such as the Cohesion Fund and the four structural funds, but also from its structural adjustment instruments.
also from a different use of the various sectoral policies that have a significant territorial impact in each region and can, therefore, have a dynamizing effect on their economies.
For the determination of European aid to these regions, it is certain that we should retain GDP as the main eligibility indicator.

However, and taking into account its natural disadvantages, it becomes relevant to resort to other measurable criteria that can provide a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or the level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more comprehensive portrait of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

Recalls the effect of the case of the outermost regions, whose status is recognized by the new treaty and which are a group of regions of the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The ultra-peripheral regions, united due to their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

Also with regard to these, supplementary GDP indicators should be employed, capable of providing a more comprehensive description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. I support this resolution calling for the need for a European strategy to operationalize the principle of cohesion.
territorial gains from the Treaty of Lisbon in opportunities for the populations of territories suffering from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

Following the Commission's communication, the ultra-peripheral regions: an asset for Europe in 2008, and after the extended debate in which the UPRs themselves participated.
Proactively, we now also await our version of this strategy, which will need to take into account not only our constraints but especially our potentialities.
I therefore call on the Commission to be swift in its presentation so that we can thus establish the best strategy before the debate on the new perspectives.

financial, because we must first define the content of the policies before allocating the necessary means for their implementation, as has been the case with the Community policies currently under review.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Commissioners, dear colleagues, after four consecutive years of declining unemployment rates from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has undone much of the progress made.
Unemployment rates in the European Union have seen a dramatic increase. For instance, in Portugal, we have unfortunately reached a record high of an 11% unemployment rate.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is thus undergoing a period of transformation and facing immense challenges.
The crisis annulled years of economic and social progress and exposed the fragilities of the economies of its member states and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
The Strategy 2020 outlines the paths to follow.
The European Union must step up all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion, as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, the proposed resolution on the future of the Social Fund, currently under discussion, is welcomed, as this fund plays a crucial role in achieving the goals of the 2020 Strategy.

In fact, this fund is the primary financial instrument that enables the European Union to achieve the strategic objectives of its employment policy, by enhancing the education and skill levels of its citizens.
The FSE should be strengthened as the main driver of the 2020 Strategy and should be used by Member States to invest in skills, employment, training, and vocational retraining.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that the reform of the European Social Fund, when carried out in conjunction with the reform of the other structural funds, should facilitate and simplify their management and...
enhance transparency, as well as focus funds on achieving results and realizing objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily lives. Thank you very much.
The European Social Fund is likely the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
should, therefore, have a strong articulation with the Regional Development Fund.
It is fundamental to take a local approach to the issues to be addressed, that is, a global perspective for local action.
Local and regional authorities are the entities most familiar with their realities, their investment needs, job creation, and the most appropriate measures for promoting employment in their regions.
We should take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an ultra-peripheral region where unemployment typically reaches record levels, the unemployment rate is 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

This is largely due to the forward-looking planning strategy employed for job creation, which defines the factors to act upon, how to achieve the desired focus, and also the use of the European Social Fund as an operational instrument of this strategy, acting on education, training, and employment promotion.
The horizontality of the cohesion policy is the only way to ensure the success of the strategy.
The cohesion policy is the cornerstone of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the entire European Union is encouraged.
In the upcoming period, from 2014 to 2020, we must establish a framework that can enhance the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at various levels should be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, respecting the principle of subsidiarity and as provided for in the new Treaty of Lisbon.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be overlooked.
This group of regions faces significant challenges and should continue to benefit in the future from specific provisions in the implementation of European policies.
GDP should continue to be the primary eligibility criterion, but we should take into account other indicators that can provide a more comprehensive picture of the regional reality.
aged and with very low birth rates.
These factors pose immense challenges for the European Union, to which we must provide concrete responses.
This observation has been consensual throughout our debate, despite the differing perspectives that this discussion has been bringing to light.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure generational renewal and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country, as it does in most member states of the European Union.
I am confident that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave can help reverse these trends.
We should send families a consistent message of support for motherhood, with concrete measures for better reconciliation of professional, private, and family life.
Women should be protected so that they can choose to have children without having to leave the labor market.
The achievement of this challenge is essential if we are to meet the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy and combat demographic aging.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already paid at 100% for 120 days, in an attempt to counteract the aforementioned decline in birth rates that we are experiencing.
I therefore argue that women's salaries should be guaranteed during maternity leave as outlined in the report under discussion.
Allowing each Member State, by 2020, to create the conditions that ensure the goal of full salary payment during maternity leave seems a prudent procedure.
Finally, I congratulate the rapporteur, Edith Estrela, for her persistence in advocating for measures aimed at protecting families, thereby helping to counteract the aging population.
Firstly, regarding these two reports, I would like to congratulate and publicly acknowledge, as I have already done in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, the remarkable work done by the...
colleagues Lena, Svoboda, Ror Berendt, Diana Wallis, and Rebeca Harms, who were part of the Parliament's team of MEPs that negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

I would also like to record the great openness and highly constructive collaborative spirit of the President of the Commission, as well as the interested and new Commission of Commissioner Shevchovich and his teams.
I believe a remarkable job has been achieved, leading to a historic agreement, which is an agreement that represents the first Framework Agreement since the signing of the Treaty.
Lisbon is the first Framework Agreement that has a direct basis, a basis expressly provided for in the treaties, more precisely in Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

I wished to say that this agreement indeed establishes a relationship of great transparency and dynamism, even a certain level of intimacy, in the connection between the Parliament and the European Union.
The Parliament and the Commission, and it essentially represents a compromise, a balance between the two institutions' visions of the new roles each should play following the Treaty of Lisbon.

I believe that the work of our negotiating team was indeed very positive because it successfully translated into this framework agreement the new competencies and the enhanced powers that arise from the Treaty of Lisbon.
This holds true for the legislative procedure and for programming or planning, namely, for instance, just to give two examples, in the involvement of Parliament in...
work program of the Commission or, for example, on issues related to the use of soft law in areas that fall within the legislative competences of the Parliament by the Commission.

On a second point, a very important aspect is the strengthening of the Parliament's control and scrutiny powers, whether in detailing and specifying the rules for the election of the President and the College of Commissioners, or, for example,

as regards the Parliament's presence in matters such as the reshuffle or the possible removal of a Commissioner, or for example, the hearing of regulatory agency directors, as well as monitoring international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there has indeed been a consolidation of powers, which are powers that stem from the Treaty of Lisbon.
Also very important is access to information, and in particular, access to classified information or that which is considered sensitive information.
confidential, and moreover, the very exchange of information and the exchange of viewpoints between the Parliament's representatives and the Commission's representatives.

or, for instance, that there are several dialogue platforms between the Conference of Presidents, the Conference of Committee Chairs, the President of the Parliament, the President of the Commission, and the College of Commissioners, all of them explicit.

I would therefore say that, with profound respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and its new balance of powers, and with profound respect for the principle of separation of powers,
Here we have a clarifying agreement that brings, that makes current, that makes alive, that makes applicable the Treaty of Lisbon.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her work, as well as acknowledging all those who collaborated with her on this report, which made it possible to reach this agreement at first reading.

This directive, which revises the previous directive dating back more than 10 years, aims, as all have recognized here, to put an end to a generalized problem within the European Union regarding payment clauses.
These delays, in some Member States, are unreasonably long when they involve the public administration.

The negative effects of this practice on economic life are enormous, both at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and at the level of the internal market. These negative effects can no longer be tolerated, all the more so as we are experiencing an economic and financial crisis like the one we are going through.
This legislative amendment provides coherence and meaning to the plan for relaunching the European economy and the implementation of the small business model.
Business Act. Undoubtedly, this directive will improve corporate liquidity.
The creators will now have an effective and efficient tool to exercise their rights against bad payers.
With this directive, the censored practice of public entities will be the exception.
Public administration bodies should set an example as upstanding citizens and pay invoices for goods and services within one month.
Now it will be up to the institutions involved, the Council, and the Member States to ensure that the transposition of this directive is carried out as soon as possible.
Today, in many Member States, there is a significant disparity regarding payment conditions to businesses, especially when the State, SMEs, and large companies are involved.

We who come from the business world know that in this situation of economic crisis and increased financing difficulties, companies are increasingly facing liquidity problems and are indeed at an elevated risk of bankruptcy in many Member States.
It seems clear that the current directive, which attempted to regulate this matter, had limited effects. Thus, the proposal we are now examining represents an important step towards fulfillment.
the payment deadlines, not only in relations between companies and public entities, but also, and this is essential, in the relations that companies establish with each other.

We now have legislation that provides us with greater added value, with a clear system of sanctions for late payments, and which also effectively improves the balance in addressing the abuse of dominant positions held by the state and large companies.
Many thanks, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. Allow me to address the unspoken.

I listened very carefully, Commissioner, and from what I have seen, it seems to me that I can say, it occurs to me to say that, so far, the most effective action, both by national authorities and European authorities, appears to have been the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and must be prevented. This is also the purpose of European legislation, and it seems obvious that the law has been violated.
There was ineffectiveness, a delayed response, abandonment of affected individuals, and particularly those most disadvantaged.
People have died, and many still today remain under the threat of what may happen to their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs, and it is immoral to neglect the victims.
How is it possible, I ask you, Commissioner, that we learn of news through accounts shared by Hungarian citizens, while the authorities see nothing or say nothing to us?
That is why I would like to raise a few questions.
How is it allowed for banks to pressure citizens with mortgaged homes in the affected area, asking them to pay what they owe, given that their homes have lost value?
How is it permitted for phone operators to cut off the only means of contact for those in the disaster zone?
How is it that the company responsible for this catastrophe is already operating again?
And lastly, Madam Commissioner, you spoke about mitigating the effects of the oil spill.
I ask you what the reasons are for continuing to mitigate the true scale of this human tragedy.
It's as if we're always starting from scratch.

Thank you, Mr. President. Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, we all acknowledge the failure in controlling macroeconomic variables in the short and long term within the European Union, particularly in the budgetary frameworks and the accumulated national debt.

The indicators that will measure the progress of the 2020 Strategy cannot be overlooked either.
The feasibility study on the issuance of common European bonds could provide an opportunity to deepen and implement financial instruments for defense against speculation.

capable of uniting and able to take a strong stance that defends the interests of citizens, and this strong stance must be recognized by the Commission and the Council.

Growth and employment require dedicated initiatives.

We are at a juncture where trust hinges on the Commission and the Council's ability to address the genuine concerns of citizens and manage unemployment, growth, and cohesion.

Within the scope of this report, I have drafted a thematic contribution for the Commission's work, emphasizing the crucial role of small and medium-sized enterprises as a driving force for the recovery of the European Union and future growth and prosperity.
In fact, there are over 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union.
Thus, if each one of them could create a job, it would mean a reduction equivalent to unemployment.
This document points to recommendations such as economic strategies for exiting the crisis, with the main ones highlighted.

the provision of tax incentives and even subsidies to SMEs to maintain and create jobs.
the creation of a new Small Business Act with a stronger social dimension.

and the Council to act, as they cannot do without an integrated European maritime policy in achieving the smart growth essential to the success of the Strategy 2020.

It draws particular attention to the biogenetic and mineral wealth potential that our deep sea and maritime bottoms enclose, which are still poorly understood today, and to the need to increase our research and development efforts in these areas.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating Mr. Commissioner Barnier on the presentation of this important document.
Just as you diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are witnessing is being felt across all sectors of society and our economy, causing our citizens despair and distrust of the single market.
but it is precisely this single market that is one of Europe's aces in the hole to combat the current crisis.
Therefore, we enthusiastically welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for single market policies, allowing us to restore confidence in our social market economy model.
In the current situation, the European Union must pay particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.
In this regard, one of the Union's priorities should be the development of mechanisms to address the issue of these companies' access to credit.

We also highlight the Commission's proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010, with the aim of facilitating the lives of these companies, particularly through bureaucratic and tax simplification, as well as through the promotion of social responsibility.

We hope that these 50 measures now presented will contribute to deepening the internal market, making full use of it, which could represent additional growth for the European economy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. We are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the European Commission's top priorities: innovation policy.
finally taking shape, notably through European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project we are discussing today on active and healthy aging.
However, there are still many aspects that need to be defined, particularly in terms of clarification, in defining future projects, and in establishing priorities.
Who, ultimately, will define the priorities and according to which criteria?
I believe these are the answers we should receive.
But I would like to make a few specific notes, particularly regarding this first project on active and healthy aging, which was the one presented to us.

And these notes are, from the outset, a positive one because it seems positive to me that they focus on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable in an increasingly aging Europe and is increasingly disadvantaged.
However, I would like to add further questions to these, as it seems contradictory to present a project in this field when, at the same time, we lack the means to support this innovation.
How are we going to sustain
Who are you?

Is there any viable innovation in a context such as the one we are witnessing, where there is a persistent and systematic attack on the Social State, a reduction in access to healthcare, systematic cuts in the services provided, and continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the presentation, "A Union of Innovation, More Employment, Improved Lives, Better Society," is ambitious.

I would even say that I would have no problem subscribing to it personally, but let's agree that it is contradictory to what has been the practice in the Member States, with the cuts and austerity measures.

I believe that there is only sustainable innovation when there are rigorous, sustainable, and demanding public policies. Otherwise, it is like a match that goes out, leaving little behind and few answers to offer these populations. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, we welcome the Commission's efforts to place research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.
We are faced with an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and productive in the service of a sustainable economy.
European partnerships for innovation emerge as an instrument and the broad challenges they address are extensive enough to avoid controversy.
However, it is still unclear how the sub-thematic priorities will be defined and how the preponderance of each discipline within them will be determined.
What level of transparency can be expected to engage stakeholders? How can conflicting interests be arbitrated?
What is the relative role of the Commission, the Member States, and the regions?
How can accountability be ensured within a structure that is complex?
What financial dimension will these partnerships have?
The Commission and the Council, Mr. President, must ensure excellence in implementation, which is not guaranteed with the scant few months of pilot testing planned for the first partnership.

The International Trade Committee is currently examining the Global Banana Agreement reached within the World Trade Organization. Let it be perfectly clear that none of the outermost regions, be it Madeira, where I come from, or any of the other eight, especially the Canaries, which are by far the most affected, are against the celebration of this type of agreement.
What these regions merely intend is that, on the one hand, the same phytosanitary conditions and respect for citizens' rights be demanded of others.
workers, which are required of them to access the market, which is a matter of basic fairness, and on the other hand, that these are compensated to the exact extent of the loss caused to them.

Either way, if this is not the case, there should be a blunt honesty in telling them that they will have to change their lives and seek other occupations, because it is certain that under the conditions that are foreseen in the future, they will not be able to survive and will have to abandon their activities.
It is true that in these agreements there are winners and losers, so let us take care of the winners because the winners do not need it.
field. We are here to discuss a very ambitious program
concrete measures to aid economic recovery, and in this case, in a central area which is the energy sector.
In the current context of the crisis we are experiencing, it is crucial that there be proposals like this one that aid in the creation of jobs.
There is no possibility of economic reconversion if we do not prioritize precisely the creation of jobs.
