This report sends a very positive signal by drawing our attention to how to respond at this level in the regional and local plans, concretely addressing local needs.
We are in a period where we are debating, and will continue to debate extensively, a set of legislative proposals in the energy sector, and often we tend to...
We focus too much on the large-scale projects, on the major networks, and overlook other levels of intervention where it is absolutely crucial to act.

And that is why I believe this report can help us to invest not only in energy efficiency and renewable energies, which is very important, but also to bring concrete benefits to local populations, which naturally translates into concrete benefits for the European population as a whole.

And that is why I would like to conclude, Mr. President, with two final points. It is important that we do not forget that energy efficiency is often achieved significantly through energy reduction in designs as well.

micro-generation, as presented here, and the final note that it was a significant gain for this Parliament to ensure there was a concrete definition of the funding amount to be applied to these projects.
This is not what we aspired to; we needed much more, and therefore, I ask the Commissioner what he aims to do and intends to do to ensure these needs are met.
Dear President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Dali, the patient must have the right to recognize, to know as much as possible about their illness and the available medications to treat it.
But how can we distinguish information from advertising?
Where and how to gather objective and unbiased information?
There are different interpretations of the texts in force. It is necessary to harmonize them, striving to reinforce the sovereignty of the citizen.
The information must be reliable, validated by authorities, independent, accessible, and targeted at a non-specialist general audience.
The aim is to foster a more informed and responsible citizenship among end-users.
The deadline given to the European Agency for tacit approval should be extended from 60 to 120 days.
The requirement for a basis of interference strengthens the contradictory and balances the final outcome.
The EMEA plays a crucial role as a privileged source of objective information.

I would like to conclude by commending Rapporteur Fielner for his work and expressing my satisfaction with the fact that he has incorporated almost all the proposals I presented in the Internal Market Committee as draftsperson of the opinion. Thank you.

Commissioner, dear colleagues, bee mortality is increasing and the number of beekeepers is decreasing. This is a problematic situation for agriculture and biodiversity, as has been mentioned here, given the enormous implications for food production and plant species that depend on their pollination.
The lifespan of a worker bee is very short, approximately six weeks, and it is highly sensitive to changes in its external environment.

Therefore, honey production has also been affected, not only by the increasingly uncertain duration and stability of the seasons, but also by the increase in external aggressions that may result from the use of pesticides, mites, or other factors.

nature and upon which the highest level of research could contribute to obtaining better applied responses and more accurate reinforcement of measures in favor of biodiversity and the reduction of the effects of climate instability.
The current programs, Commissioner, undoubtedly need to be strengthened within the framework of the new CAP, so that here too, at this level, we can achieve a more effective level of response.
Mr. President, let us be clear, the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work, nor does it work. The price of Greek debt did not decrease, Ireland is in...

The economic convolution and contagion were not contained. The process that was created was done so belatedly, is intergovernmental, and should have existed in a different format from the very beginning of the euro's creation.
The President of the Commission is now proposing to us a consolidation of this system.
However, in the third of the instruments it proposes to use, it suggests involving the private sector.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a result of this premature and ill-timed announcement that the markets surged.
The Parliament will fully utilize its powers with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the co-decision process accompanying the package.
legislative action on economic governance, but it will not do so at the expense of haste and speed, relegating quality to second place.

Therefore, let us be clear, the Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the resolution of sovereign debt cannot be decided without and against the European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are intertwined.
Lastly, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this time of crisis.

A European mechanism for the consolidation of sovereign debt is necessary, as is the issuance of eurobonds, and the eurozone must be sustainably protected through European, not intergovernmental, systems.
It is necessary to reinforce the European budget; we cannot continue with a budget of this magnitude. Growth and real convergence must be placed at the heart of European political priorities.
This is the agenda that the Commission and the new President must uphold.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I would of course like to say that the EPP's position is clear. It is a position in favor of...
that the resolution of this crisis, this severe crisis facing Europe and the European Union, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the communal method.

For us, there is no doubt that only with more community method, only with economic governance, only with the proper instruments of a true single currency in the euro area, can this crisis be confronted and addressed.
But this means that each of the institutions, the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament, must assume their responsibilities before the Europeans.
And it must be said that it is clear here that, at least, the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate visibly with a view to increasing.
the community method, of introducing economic governance, of providing the single currency with the necessary conditions to succeed in the context of the European crisis.

It is also evident today that the same is true of the Commission and its President, who, contrary to what the Socialists and Member Elisa Ferreira claim, has demonstrated that he is neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of Parliament, but an emanation of European interest.
It remains for the Council, now in December, to assume its responsibilities.
It is on this that we rely, and on your clear commitment to the European ideal, President Van Rompuy.
Many thanks, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating colleagues Luan and Manescu on the remarkable work they have done in their respective reports.
both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 horizon.
Today, more than ever, achieving economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for asserting the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by strengthening and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe internally and competitive externally.

In this particular aspect, I would highlight three crucial points. Firstly, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, are more involved and contribute to the better implementation of the cohesion policy.

Member States should invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of structural funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives. Lastly, the role of regional authorities should be strengthened in the preparation, management, and implementation of programs.
Only in this way, with the greatest involvement of these authorities throughout the entire process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect I deem crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of the funds.
The underlying major concern of the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us not only do that, but also make your life easier by avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that are deterrents to your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to achieve the goal of true territorial cohesion.
Only then will we see the disparities within the European Union reduced, which are currently starkly contrasting with a huge gap between rich and poor regions.
Greater participation also means greater responsibility. It is this responsibility that must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues. Firstly, I would like to congratulate Edith Bauer and Anne Ed, my fellow colleagues, for the excellent work carried out in this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and demands a strong and coordinated response from all.
The organized crime that lies behind sexual exploitation, forced labor, the trade in human organ extraction, and other abominable practices must be effectively combated, but primarily prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable people, namely women and children.
The experience demonstrated that the legal framework in place was not sufficiently effective and that the European Union needs to commit further.
It is essential to have greater cross-border cooperation, including effective sharing of information and best practices.
In this proposal, a victim-centered approach is appropriately emphasized.
Policies in this field should encompass aspects related to social affairs and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, and therefore, allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country regarding this Summit.
At that time, the Portuguese authorities prohibited the entry of European citizens into the country for a single reason: these citizens carried with them critical texts of the Alliance.
In these days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime prevailed in Portugal, an authentic thought police.
a regime so special that it led the Portuguese government to purchase anti-riot gear worth 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are, after all, the priorities of a government facing a massive social crisis.
In the Europe we envision, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we envision does not bow down to military organizations that write their history in blood.
From the NATO summit emerged the legitimization of its military intervention across the globe.
Also evident is the subordination of the European Union to American military strategy and interests.
In third place, the militarization of access to energy sources was consolidated.
Lastly, the military defense of the development model that generates environmental imbalances and exacerbates the social crisis was established.
By this, I mean, Madam President, that, in my understanding, with this summit we lose in democracy, we lose in freedom, and we lose so that some can profit from war.

And now I give the floor to Mr. Rangel. He has one and a half minutes. Thank you, Madam President. The first point I would like to make clear here, and which is important to emphasize in this Parliament, is that...

It is that, contrary to what sometimes appears to be read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in an extremely difficult situation, with the currencies of the weaker countries undergoing massive devaluation and a potential German mark appreciating to a level unsustainable for both the German and European economies.
And, therefore, the euro was a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries in the eurozone, but also for the currencies of the countries that chose not to join the eurozone.

And for that very reason, because we have to defend this community that was able to respond to the crisis like no other, and as we will indeed see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro actually has advantages.

We now have the responsibility within this Council to do everything to defend the euro, to create in particular a stabilization fund that follows the community method and that is able to introduce responsibility into...

countries that are in a more vulnerable position and solidarity with those that have fulfilled their obligations and that have not always shown, at least through their external statements, a willingness to be supportive within the eurozone context.

I would like to offer my sincere congratulations to colleague Sarbu for the excellence of the report produced, and I strongly advise that the Commission take it into consideration, especially in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues, which far exceed the strict scope of...

agriculture, require the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market, and financial regulation, as well as their consideration in other international forums, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The issues that are absolutely decisive for agriculture, for farmers, and for ensuring the availability of sufficient quantities and qualities of food for the populations of Europe and the world can only be effectively addressed if they are tackled in all their dimensions.

And the ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform goes beyond the strict boundaries of agriculture and its objectives are also taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global bodies.
This report made it abundantly clear, and I commend it for that.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues. I would like to begin by expressing my gratitude for all the words spoken here regarding the report that Parliament presents on Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.
We all know that the situation we are facing is substantially dramatic and is still greatly underdiagnosed. This has been mentioned here.
and I would like to briefly mention an issue that was prevalent in all the interventions, but perhaps not emphasized enough, which is the matter of patient dignity and their rights,
and not only of the patients, but also of their families and caregivers, whether formal or informal, and of the professionals associated with this type of disease.

I am truly pleased, indeed delighted, with the Commissioner's words when he states that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations in the report presented by Parliament very positively and will do everything in its power to implement them.
We are aware that each passing day is later than the previous one in this matter, given the urgency of what we have at hand.
And therefore, we also know that tomorrow the Parliament will pronounce on this matter.
We will await the outcome of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral support.

They expect concrete and appropriate actions from us. I sincerely hope, Commissioner, that you will then put this into practice, and that the Commission, which has the initiative—unfortunately, this Parliament does not—will implement it.

all this priority you claim to give to this area and transform it into legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with the equality and dignity they deserve. Thank you very much.

Firstly, I would like to state that this Parliament, on a day when we are discussing the Hungarian presidency, without prejudice to addressing all the issues it intends to, should focus on the problems of the European Union, which it is not doing here.
And to focus on the issues of the European Union, you should read carefully and discuss here whether you agree or not with the priorities of the Hungarian presidency, instead of discussing points.
or aspects that are internal matters of Hungary and which, at most, can be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Government and Parliament.

I would therefore like to say here that, in addition to the priority that the Hungarian Presidency will naturally give to the economic and financial issues on the agenda, I am very pleased to see that
The Hungarian agenda for this semester is both lucid and ambitious, focusing and prioritizing three subjects that will be essential for Europe's future.

the food system, which is now facing a severe global crisis, the energy that is essential for our security and economic sustainability, and water, which few have discussed, but which will be, after food, the next major challenge for Europeans.
I hope you achieve your goals.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that these two countries, like others in the region, demonstrate how, in recent years, European leaders have often prioritized business over democracy, and dictators over the impoverished.
I am frankly concerned about the situation currently unfolding in Egypt and today's developments, which is why I believe we should not remain calm but instead show solidarity.
solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens, both men and women, in Cairo and across the country, weary of hunger, weary of oppression, weary of unemployment.
And that is why, after today's speech by Mubarak, after the regime's dogs have been unleashed, after creating an open and clear path for violence, we must say that we have to stand by these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created to make them return home.
Thirty-six years ago, in Portugal, we would have returned home if we had heeded this advice.
Fortunately, we didn't return because then we would have had a democratic revolution.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to say that I believe this issue is too important for us to continue living in the deception we have experienced in Europe.
either a mistake or a false promise, as you may call it, because we have been operating, especially in the collection of umbilical cord stem cells, based on misleading information.
And we know, as has been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of umbilical cord stem cells does not reach one percent.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for treating diseases may be inexhaustible, diseases such as those already mentioned, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, rare diseases—the possibilities are immense.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a network of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children's cells, at the time of birth, and thus potentially cure them in the future, if needed.
I believe we should be more responsible than that, because the likelihood of ensuring this happens is very low, as we know.
And this false promise sold to parents comes at a cost.
In Portugal, for example, this false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly lies in creating public banks of stem cells, as only through public banks can we ensure equal use and equal access.
and effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for all, and not just using stem cells as a commodity or a growing business that is only accessible to a few.
Therefore, I believe that solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not, after all, things that can be classified as additional requirements.
We do not have the power to enforce, but we have the power to promote.
This falls within our scope of responsibilities, I believe we should act in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Food prices have reached an all-time high and this is the seventh consecutive time they have increased.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first of which is a short-term factor.
has to do with the coincidence of poor weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina,
but there are two structuring factors, they are of a structuring nature, and that is why I am bringing up these two factors here.
The first aspect relates to the fact that some food producers and consumers who were previously exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
And the second factor relates to the ability of some large multinationals to manipulate prices in their favor.
And the example of cereals is very clear at this level. It is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation thus places farmers in a state of great uncertainty regarding food product prices.
Europe must, therefore, resume doing what it stopped doing some time ago, namely, protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone turns to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
I would like to congratulate my fellow rapporteur, Marisa Matias, and acknowledge all those who collaborated with her.
Regrettably, in recent years, we have witnessed a rise in the counterfeiting of medicines in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to European patients and the European industry.
The objective of this directive is to prevent the introduction of falsified medicines into the supply chain and thereby protect public health.

I would like to emphasize the following key points in the opinion I have drafted. The introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, with a clear focus on consumer protection. The application of provisions...

safety for prescription medicines, the accountability of all stakeholders in the distribution chain, and finally, the application by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
President, I obviously want to thank all the comments made by all the colleagues, both male and female.
I will not comment on each one individually; that is not the intention here.
I believe that if there were any doubts about what the word "commitment" means, it was made perfectly clear here what commitment entails.

We may not all have the perfect proposal, but what is far more important than knowing if it is perfect is realizing that we hold an instrument in our hands that will enable us to no longer postpone the protection of patient health.
And we have the obligation not to postpone its adaptation either, we have the obligation not to delay real action, and we can only do this together.
I must also say personally, and Commissioner mentioned the issue of inspections, in my initial proposal I presented an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
The commitment is precisely this, and yet, one gains in some aspects and loses in others.
We were explained by the Commission that this would be impossible to obtain.
I would like to make one more note regarding this commitment.
I believe that we all see ourselves in the commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding in order for it to be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

It is through this commitment that safeguards are ensured, allowing us to monitor the process, assess, and systematically receive information that enables us to verify whether it is being implemented or not, properly or not, and whether changes are necessary.

I therefore wish to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its cooperation, in particular the Spanish Presidency and the Belgian Presidency, with whom we have worked closely over the past six months.
There are no perfect proposals, no perfect interventions, there are flaws, but I believe we have a strong and robust commitment to enable us to fight for and defend patient health.
And since my intervention is also full of flaws, I failed to thank colleagues Regina Bastos and Amalia Sartori, from the partners of the other committees.
Many thanks also for your support.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the current moment is the most serious test of the euro's survival and, therefore, of Europe.
The Polimata report opens up constructive solutions, and for this reason, I also want to congratulate our colleague on the ideas presented.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the fact that the eurozone as a whole has an excessive external deficit or debt. Rather, it arises from the persistent and severe divergence of the economies that comprise it, under the impact of common policy.
And we lack instruments that enable convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that enable Europe to grow.
Let's be clear, the Eurozone and the European Union cannot survive with the current level of integration and the diversity of the economies that make it up, with a budget of 1% of collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to construct was the recipe of austerity, and it is the workers and businesses who are paying the price today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, in the rescue of which 26% of the European Union's wealth was committed.
The financial transactions tax, with a very low rate, for instance, zero point zero five, applied to high-risk, highly speculative product transactions, it is true, shall be borne by their consumers.
But why should they not pay if ordinary citizens pay VAT on bread, on milk, and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed to harm fewer workers and businesses and be shared more evenly across financial sectors, especially speculative ones.
And, Commissioner, I believe it is not for the Commission, at this moment, to reject or dodge the clear message that, politically, this Parliament is sending you.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions; on the contrary, it must be examined with the highest priority.
We know very well what happened with the A flu, and it should serve as a lesson for all of us.
And I don't know if you remember well how all this started, but the truth is that it began in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the scale of the problem.
That is why the report voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the entire story unfolded, and who determined that it should have happened this way.
As we have the right to know which countries responded in a particular way, why they responded without transparency and without allowing us to stay informed...

minimum of doubt, because we have maintained all doubts as to whether or not there was a deal. We need to have the assurance that no trace remains as to whether or not there was a deal related to this flu.
And that is why I understand, Madam President, that all threats to public health must be addressed, but it is not indifferent how they are addressed or who pays for them.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. We are here discussing proposals on wages and proposals on the retirement age, and the least we can say about these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
It is unfair to insist on recipes that have been proven time and again to be failed recipes.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy, and who knows how many other countries, because this is an endless cadence, are different situations in each of these countries, but there are some things in common.
One of the things we have in common is an unprecedented transfer of value from labor to financial capital.
We cannot accept this.
The other thing we have in common is that those paying for this crisis are the workers, retirees, and pensioners. Also paying for it is an entire generation of precarious workers who...
There is no guarantee of any kind in the society we live in. That is why I would like to conclude by saying, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I sincerely hope.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by stating that I fully support what was said by my colleague.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of immense importance and growing significance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of procedural intentions and timelines.
but there is a very complicated problem, as already mentioned.

The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but it does so in a very, very lengthy timeframe, from nine months to a year, and this is after the disaster has occurred.

As has also been mentioned, and I reiterate and will continue to emphasize exhaustively for as long as necessary, there is the case of Madeira. A year ago, it suffered a massive catastrophe and has still not received any support.
And I ask this, and I reiterate the question, is it not time for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and the financing model itself?
How can we maintain an exception fund to address situations that are increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen, and climate change is here to prove it.
Therefore, an exception can never respond to a situation of regularity. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are highly sensitive and of utmost importance to our populations, and should not be taken lightly.

We are discussing very sensitive situations that affect people's safety and their property, which often stir emotions due to the loss of lives, destroyed families, and the devastation of entire working lives.

Yet, all our demonstrations are of little avail amidst the media-driven dramas that impress and sensitize us all, if we then fall asleep on the job of doing the work required to prevent, minimize, or better assist in those situations.
Commissioner, the matter has been very well addressed by my colleagues.

It is a field where the European Union can best demonstrate its presence to its citizens, helping them in disaster prevention, especially when such events occur, and standing by their side in the moments when they are most in need and most vulnerable.
I will gladly respond, although I did not intend to turn a debate in the European Parliament into a discussion on Portuguese politics.

In fact, if Deputy Edith Estrela wishes to debate Portuguese politics, there is a simple solution. We should hold elections, with candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and she will have the opportunity, in opposition, to debate the PSD government's policies for Portugal.
I will only say this: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times in the span of two years.
It is impossible, unsustainable, not credible to the markets, there are no more solutions with the socialist government.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Ms. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I begin by congratulating colleague Schwab for his persistent negotiation, which led to this important agreement, and I also acknowledge all those who collaborated with him on this report.

We aim not only to guarantee a high level of protection for European consumers but also to ensure that European businesses, regardless of their size, can supply goods and services to consumers in the 27 member states without unnecessary legal barriers.

This new directive will put an end to the legislative fragmentation that has been hindering our companies' participation in the cross-border market and will provide a significant boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions concerning the information to be provided to the consumer, requiring this information to be clear, intelligible, and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof regarding compliance with information requirements now falls on the merchant.
As for contracts concluded at a distance, especially those completed by phone or over the internet, their rules should be defined, and consumers protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are confident that, at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is required in a global economy. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, and Mr. President of the Commission. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate you on the outcomes of the Council of 24 and 25 March, particularly the consolidation of the semester.

European, but much more than that, whether through the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, or the closure, so to speak, of the Euro Plus Pact, which had already been initiated at the Eurozone Summit on March 11th.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe, and it is a shame that this process was not fully completed on March 24th and 25th.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the States had given that signal in the Council, by fully closing this fund reform package, we would be in a position today.

stronger to face the 3, 4 months ahead. In part, we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and about which I also wish to say a few words.
To state that, in the case of the PSD, fully integrated within the EPP, there is an absolute and total willingness to meet the requirements and obligations of integration into the European area.
This is what we have been doing, even now, at this very moment, amidst difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike what the Socialist Government has done, the Social Democrat Party has demonstrated full willingness to provide Europe with any guarantees necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this, I want to give this signal, without bringing domestic politics into the European Parliament, of the fulfillment, the commitment, and the Social Democratic Party's full guarantee in the rigorous agenda that the country will have to adopt after its elections on June 5th.
Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Fule. The historic moment we are living calls for firm and determined action.
Like many of you, we are watching the events unfolding in the Mediterranean Basin with a mix of hope, concern, and anticipation.

I nonetheless feel satisfied with the proactive stance that Parliament is set to adopt regarding the review of the European Union's Southern Neighborhood Policy, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this region, not only as a payer, but also as a committed partner.
first and foremost by asserting the absolute necessity of upholding our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise on the defense of democracy, nor on the defense of human rights, and even less on the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the higher interests of citizens and their unwavering defense, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to the rights of women.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is imperative that this happens.
Only greater involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express my frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not wish to seize this opportunity to finally differentiate the Eastern Neighborhood Policy with countries that could potentially become our partners in the Union in the future from the Southern Neighborhood Policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20th, the ambition that the current moment demands, a neighborhood policy.
Taylor Made, tailored to each State, with clear benchmarks and a careful assessment that can lead to a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the South.

To conclude, Commissioner, we trust that the positive atmosphere and cooperation that have characterized the work on this subject will lead to a permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Many thanks, Mr. President. The reports we have debated, and I congratulate the rapporteurs, reinforce a series of initiatives aimed at revitalizing the internal market.
I would like to emphasize the commitment of the European Commission, in particular Commissioner Barnier, whom I applaud, and the positive reception of this Parliament through the...
Consumer Protection and Internal Market Committee, to prioritize the competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the Strategy 2020.
Citizens and businesses anticipate effective impulses for Europe's economic growth to resume, they expect an increase in employment, and they aspire to create greater prosperity.

And, as the Commissioner emphasized, opening markets to our companies, by eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and a unique opportunity that will enable them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

Measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs, and their access to credit and the services market, as well as the European patent and recognition of qualifications, are essential.
the relevance of developing electronic commerce to strengthen consumer and business confidence in this type of trade, the focus on innovation.
Social entrepreneurship is crucial for robust and sustainable growth. It is indispensable in creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening, and making full use of the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation that Member States redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also wish to add my voice to those who have expressed concerns about the low earnings of fishermen, exacerbated by the historic high prices of fuels, especially in recent months.

As has been very rightly pointed out here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, exacerbating in particular the already fragile revenues from fishing.
This vestigial rise in prices is also bringing us profound negative effects. Reduced trips to sea, misery wages for fishermen exacerbated by low prices paid at first sale.

increases in imports from third countries of aquaculture and fisheries products into the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, with further job losses.
In this context, to prevent the continuation of the deepening of the crisis, it is necessary to act and to act with severity and in-depth on fishing issues.

The Commission must, therefore, provide positive responses with short- and long-term measures to address the adversities facing the sector and the severe income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
Mario, esteemed rapporteur, firstly, I would like to congratulate, in particular, the work of our PPE colleague, Mario David, whom I represent here today due to his absolute...
enabled to attend this plenary session and would like to state that we have always considered supporting the victims of the floods in Pakistan to be an ethical and moral imperative.
Therefore, we strongly support all measures that have been taken towards traditional humanitarian aid.
We truly believe that efforts should continue to be made to help stabilize the situation of so many millions of people affected.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered an appropriate and suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this has two dire consequences. One consequence is within the European Union, particularly for the countries of the South and their textile and clothing industry, now highly vulnerable due to an unprecedented economic, social, and financial crisis since...

entry into the Union. Secondly, at a global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening up of the world's largest trading bloc, which is the European Union, to potential Pakistani exports could completely destabilize the negotiations.
And it is not by chance that they find themselves in the impasse they are in.

It is, therefore, natural that, faced with such a situation, we must say, in light of the history of this regulation and the difficulties it encountered during these eight months of intense negotiations.

In collaboration, we endorse the most constructive proposals, and unfortunately, we must now take a stance. This position supports the amendment that fundamentally calls for the conclusion of this regulatory proposal as we know it.
We must do so at this moment, not out of lesser solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be provided in the proper place and in the proper manner.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to begin by saying that, of course, I believe the agreement reached for Portugal is a balanced one.
This is a very tough agreement for populations, but it places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I believe that this is very positive.

I do not adopt the stance of others who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland, and Portugal did everything right, made no mistakes, did not overreact, and did everything correctly, and that it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments have erred and pursued mistaken policies. But this does not mean that there is not now an opportunity, within the context of the Union, to have the possibility of getting back on the right track and the correct path.

And therefore, it is important to recall here that, in fact, one must tell the public opinions that are against supporting countries in distress that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to them.
but they are lending them at very high interest rates and, therefore, they are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.
But I also say here that perhaps it is time for a comprehensive European response with the introduction of eurobonds, and the possibility of primary market sales to address international markets.

And perhaps it is time for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF to review interest rates, in order to provide the possibility of, by lowering these rates, achieving sustained growth in these countries that are currently in difficulty.

Thank you. I give the floor to Mr. Correia de Campos for one minute. Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially those whose economies require greater competitiveness.
is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises
Today is the most active generation of new jobs.
It is essential for universities and laboratories whose relationship with productive sectors is partly dependent on their survival.
It is essential for the financial system, which will find, in innovation, a new market as the classic manufacturing model exhausts itself.

Innovation is at the forefront of the European agenda and, as a pillar of the EU 2020 Strategy, must be supported by new financial instruments to prevent it from succumbing to cyclical budgetary constraints.
I would like to finally welcome Judith Merckx for her significant contribution to a more innovative Europe with an economy more grounded in knowledge. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Odi on his excellent report.

The interim evaluation, although belated, allowed for the highlighting of the critical aspects of the seventh program, its excessive bureaucracy, industry disinterest, the number and complexity of new instruments, and the slow pace of disbursements.
There is also a greater risk of substantial transfers of funds from the current framework program to large-scale programs of questionable added value.

but it also allowed for highlighting positive aspects, greater articulation and international cooperation among scientific groups in joint projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a more balanced gender representation.
There are priorities that need to be developed. Firstly, simplification. Secondly, promoting scientific excellence, not in some countries, but across Europe. A stronger link between...

Framework program with innovation, featuring instruments targeted at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar program, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, I will address directly the proposal that has been presented to Parliament today, and I will say with complete candor that I believe we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal. Not only is it weak, but it also contains significant gaps.
I believe this is a European issue, not a matter of states with nuclear industry and those without. It concerns the entirety of Europe, and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I, frankly, must say that one of these good news items is to assure citizens that we are taking care of their security.

Well, when these tests are carried out in the terms presented by the Commissioner, that is, a first phase is carried out by the interested parties themselves, a second phase is carried out by the States which...

These stakeholders defend their interests. And a third phase is carried out by those who are truly interested, and I wonder if the result won't be to ultimately say that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and are highly recommended.

We know this is not the case, and therefore, I sincerely hope that there will be serious consequences and that we can assure our citizens that we are taking care of their safety and not just pretending to do so. Thank you very much.
I expect from this European Council, especially given the climate of recent weeks, a decision of great responsibility.
and more responsibility than there was in the last Council, where an attempt was made to postpone a problem for three months solely due to electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision, fundamentally, will demonstrate that economic and financial matters are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that they are instrumental to what is the primary purpose of Europe—the goal of maintaining peace.
if an approach to problems is taken that merely leads to states beginning to distrust each other, to instill distrust among the different states.
fostering and exacerbating differences and rivalries between Southern and Northern states, between central and peripheral states. What we will be led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of technical solutions, regardless of political disagreements, is whether we want the European project to remain a valid strategy for peace in Europe or not.
Check what is at stake here.
What I notice in many speeches by leaders, both those from countries in distress and those from countries that are payer nations.
contributors, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to certain characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I appeal, and only to this, to the sense of responsibility of the leaders of European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a solution.

Many thanks, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. My first words are to commend the work carried out by the rapporteur, colleague Giorgio Stavrakakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness among the various structural funds.

Your report also falls within this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate of utmost importance not only due to the substance of the topic but also, and primarily, because of the timing of its discussion.
Indeed, we are now in the process of becoming acquainted with the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives but also concerning the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its instruments par excellence, the structural funds, finances projects and programs in the Member States, aiming to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
Experience, however, has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results that arise from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

Thus, a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for achieving greater and better synergies among the different instruments and enhancing their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination among various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in resource allocation.
We must seize the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

It is certain that all these reports that are under discussion here today will present enormous challenges. And we know that to meet these challenges, we also need a good budget. But we must make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
Political objectives are well-known, and indeed, it is only by asserting these political goals that we can offer a future for the regions.
And if this is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and citizens, and not the citizens and regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and a single currency, requires a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions in order to function effectively.
The current competitiveness divergences, the development asymmetries, have inevitably led to the fragilization of the European space and the crisis affecting the eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a strong cohesion budget, one that cannot be weakened to fund other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must have more. And this is achieved by growing its budget, not by reducing, even skillfully, the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask the Commissioner whether the establishment of the Infrastructure Fund and the new innovation policies, which will be articulated with cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, could become the Trojan horse introduced into the cohesion budget.
The modernization and renewal of energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and smart growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security we require.
It is indispensable to engage all regions in this challenge.

To achieve this, the incentives provided for in regulatory systems should be enhanced, particularly those applicable to higher-risk and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores Islands in the field of renewable energies.

Regions should be associated with the design and implementation phases of projects, in defining priorities, in their development and execution, as this ensures better results and thus a stronger defense of European interests.
The current economic climate further emphasizes the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental, and social aspects.
It is indispensable not to lose sight of its medium- and long-term effects, seeking to ensure all European citizens have access to secure, sustainable, and affordably priced energy.

The report we are debating is of particular importance, given the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation, and economic growth.

Collaboration with rapporteur Proncias de Roça was very fruitful and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself has just stated, enabling the adoption of several compromises in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee.
For the result we have here today and which we have debated, I congratulate and commend the rapporteur.
In fact, from our perspective, the main concern was to make it clear that competencies in this matter lie with the Member States.
National authorities are the holders of the powers to define, organize, and fund social services of general interest.
Thus, there is no need for the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level, given the great diversity of these social services of general interest in the 27 Member States.

Simply look at health services, social security, employment services, and social housing, which are examples that demonstrate how understanding local contexts and building relationships are cornerstone to the proper and fair delivery of these services. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, as the rapporteur for the REGI Committee's opinion on the future of social services of general interest, I would like to congratulate my colleague from Portugal, emphasizing the fact that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we advocate for Europe, in which SGIs play a crucial role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level recommends that the existence of minimum protection levels in all Member States should not be overlooked, without prejudice to the respect for the competences of their national, regional, and local authorities.

European regions play a crucial role in providing these services to their populations, and their perspective should be considered, given the unique nature of their constraints, to ensure the effective delivery of these services to the people.

In a time of crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing, social services of general interest form a social safety net for the most disadvantaged or for those whose incomes do not allow them access to private services.

Yes, it is important to ensure that Member States which decentralize powers do so with the accompanying financial resources, so that regional and local authorities can guarantee their effective delivery to the population.
Mrs. Ashton, I begin by stating that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time, and therefore, I just want to leave a few notes.
Firstly, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, with a view to a democratic transition and not civil war, have to be defined by the peoples of these countries.
The situation in Syria is grave, this applies to Syria, but it also applies to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we wish to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to meddle in their internal affairs, especially and particularly through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, I say it because we must totally repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have exceeded all resolutions, including those voted on by the United Nations Security Council.
And it is this silence regarding Libya, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it is not included in this resolution that I cannot endorse it. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. Firstly, I would of course like to congratulate the Polish Presidency on the ambitious program it has brought here and, in particular, to congratulate them on...

neighborhood policy, not only to the east but also on the southern border, where I believe we are currently facing a challenge that is perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, which is more long-term and less short-term.

With that said, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay particular attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and the supervision of financial markets.

I believe that at this moment, no matter how ambitious our goals are in areas such as defense, energy, food security, the environment, agriculture, and multi-annual financial frameworks, if we do not...

Unless we resolve the issue of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid manner before the global markets, we will not have a Europe strong enough to face the challenges that the Polish presidency has set out to address.

And, therefore, I drew attention to the fact that it is fundamental to convince the remaining heads of state and government that it is necessary to give the European Union more economic integration, more economic governance.

Without this, what will happen is that we, instead of being the leaders, or at least the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, or in Parliament, or in the Commission of European Interest, instead of fulfilling this role, we will be merely...
Mr. President, as Chairman of the Mach Req Delegation, I would like to make a brief statement about each of my four countries, in quotes, of course.
Beginning with Syria, and reiterating what some colleagues have also stated, it is regrettable that the international community appears, in the eyes of public opinion, to have a double standard.

It is necessary to call out, if need be, the countries on the Security Council, and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, as well as Brazil, but with the right to veto, which have prevented the international community from taking a more coherent position in line with the values we share.
With regard to Egypt, I believe there is an urgent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities about postponing the elections, as has already been done in Tunisia.
As for Lebanon, I believe that this debate must result in a very clear message to the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their actions in relation to the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

Regarding Jordan, it serves as an example that a peaceful transition is possible and that, at this stage, there is perhaps only a need to raise awareness and encourage authorities to expedite the process of reforms.
Obviously, in a debate of this kind, we cannot overlook the peace process in the Middle East and must reiterate our hope that the Quartet meeting next Monday can...
effectively be productive and reiterate that this House would certainly like to see much greater involvement by the European Union in the entire process.

I have no doubt that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September, but I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and conducted in good faith.
Many thanks, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will continue to constitute a reference point regarding recommendations and robust, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If the conclusion to be drawn is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome through the deepening of European integration.

In a time of severe financial, economic, and social difficulties, and painful austerity measures in some Member States, such as my country, Portugal, there is a temptation to seek refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But I know one mistake.

The European response to the crisis requires a genuine European economic government pursuing sustainable growth, promoting job creation, and developing the social market economy. It should provide long-term solutions with defined objectives that Member States can identify with.
The crisis exit strategy needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avert a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination on fiscal policies is necessary, along with the establishment of a system for issuing public debt securities and euro-bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that during this challenging period, it is also essential to maintain social protection levels, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Presidency-in-Office, it is often said that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, that has been the case, but today I am not so certain that this remains true.

The slow, improvised, reactive manner in which the Union is responding to the Greek crisis exacerbates the situation daily and spreads contagion and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening way.
This despite the eurozone's problems stemming from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, which today are concentrated in its weakest links.

In order for the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is necessary, as there was in the past, which unfortunately neither the Commission nor the Council has been able to instill in the program and the European project.
This parliamentary report, however, provides us with this insight. More Europe, not less, is the solution.
The Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency create unbearable divergences between economies and that these must be counteracted by specific policies.

Acknowledges that the functioning of the euro requires a reinforced European budget with own resources, requires a European agency for the joint issuance of debt, capable of protecting states from market speculation.

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that the portability of diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
The Parliament has united to send clear messages. Let us hope that the Commission and the Council heed them.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear rapporteur colleague, firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate and commend the rapporteur colleague for considering this report extremely useful. It indeed allows us to take new steps in the field of mediation.
The report provides an overview, a range of solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation, in the application of...
European Parliament and Council Directive 2852-CE of 21 May 2008 on mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Well, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is an extrajudicial means of resolving conflicts, contributing to the decongestion of courts, rationalizing the justice system, while also providing
simultaneously offering the parties the possibility of obtaining a friendly, faster, and less costly solution than the litigation in which they are engaged.

In other words, it is crucial to reaffirm the objective of Article 1 of the directive when it calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods and, in particular, mediation.
Promoting access to and use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution contributes to improving, simplifying, and making our justice system more accessible.

It is, therefore, a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security, and justice; I would say, for the concept of the rule of law within the European Union.
And it is for this reason, in this context of crisis as well, that I consider it highly important, as the report states, to raise awareness among the general public and operators.
judiciary for this subject matter and call on the Commission and Commissioner to rapidly submit a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution.
Many thanks, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to highlight the fundamental importance of this report in terms of transparency in the European energy market.
And I just want to say that this is a central area of cooperation in European terms, if we preserve some of the dimensions that are fundamental. Among them, preventing the...
ensure that liberalization does not result in higher energy prices for citizens, guarantee equal access, and exercise caution regarding sanctions, as several colleagues have already mentioned.
And, precisely because this is a central area of European cooperation, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I cannot help but refer to it and question it, and ask the Commissioner face to face.
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain yourself regarding the recent statements you made about Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, as these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures such as raising the flags at half-mast, Mr. Commissioner, only serve to deepen the shame felt by citizens who are worthy and who strive for a better Europe.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Shevkovich, Ladies and Gentlemen of the Council, Polish Presidency. Firstly, I would like to clarify that I will be speaking here in a dual capacity. On the one hand, I am replacing the author of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs.

constitutional matters, my colleague Messer Schmidt, a Dane, who is absent as the election process is underway in Denmark at this moment, and therefore I am representing him as a member from Africa, but also as a member of the Jury, serving as shadow rapporteur on the Jury for this report.
The first point I wanted to make is that, in the crisis we are facing, the economic and financial crisis, the issue of smart regulation, of better legislation, is a central one.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms that can drive the economic and financial recovery of the European area, the improvement at the level of legislation and regulation is also absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe which aims to be dynamic and competitive must have simple and accessible regulations for businesses and, of course, for citizens as well. Therefore, it must be tailored to their needs.
The truth is that, in this regard, it is essential today that, first and foremost, the program for reducing administrative burdens be achieved, and that every effort be made towards...

promote consultations with market agents, representative associations of citizens and companies, and conduct an impact assessment of the legislation itself, this is also extremely important, in order to...

The decision-making process can essentially be based, let us say, precisely on the opinion of those who are the intended beneficiaries of the legislation, and this can be achieved without administrative burdens and with fewer economic and financial costs.

It is important to note that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the concept of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be appropriate and not one that promotes the complexity of the system.

legal and regulatory system. Therefore, in our view, we have paid particular attention to the enhanced role that National Parliaments now play in this dynamic, precisely due to the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that we now involve National Parliaments, both at the level of Smart Regulation and in improving legislation, so that both legislation and regulation are effective at the European level and at the national level.

be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And, therefore, this is a good moment to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through smarter regulation.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has continued to rise in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial, and social crisis, and the rise in unemployment, have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is a denial of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity, and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for instance, which is subject to stringent austerity measures, the concept of homelessness, as per the National Plan, includes individuals who seek assistance to obtain a meal.
and the number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
A more significant increase is noted among disadvantaged families and individuals whose living conditions have been altered by unemployment and also by banking indebtedness.
This is just one example that demonstrates the severity of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament adopted a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament highlighted the need for the European Union to equip itself with a strategy underpinned by national and regional strategies, with the long-term goal of ending situations where people sleep on the streets and the state of long-duration homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policies of the Member States.
We took careful note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the point he made.
I conclude by urging the European Commission to give a strong impetus to coordinate the action of the Member States and regional authorities to tackle this social injustice. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, we have debated the peace process in the Middle East, but is there some ongoing process that has escaped my attention?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union, in line with the majority of the international community, repeatedly affirms the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, who have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, entrenching themselves in a growing spiral of hatred and misunderstandings that has lasted for 63 years, only extremism and frustration are fueled.

It is crucial that Europe and the Arab League become much more engaged in the pursuit of a negotiated solution for the borders, based on those existing in 1967, with adjustments that allow the majority of Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the issue of Jerusalem, the holy city and future capital of both states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who are obligated to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that this is a land of milk and honey.

that all countries of the Union participate in resolving the issue of Palestinian refugees and that the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, contribute to the necessary financial compensation.

It is still absolutely essential that a military force under the aegis of the UN and with the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces be deployed as a guarantor of the maintenance of peace.
Thus, let there be courage and political will.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, tourism requires a clear and coordinated European approach, with a keen eye on the potential and challenges that the different tourism models have to offer.
The tourist diversity that the European Union offers is so rich that it allows for exponential growth in this sector and in the European Union's own competitiveness.

A bet in this key sector, which accounts for 10% of GDP and approximately 12% of employment in the European Union, will enable not only the creation of European added value but also the response to the economic crisis we are facing.
It originates from an ultra-peripheral region, Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

Therefore, the creation of a specific funding line for the sector within the 2014-2020 financial framework is indispensable for the cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially made up of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The implementation of a genuine European policy for sustainable and diverse tourism requires a concrete strategic plan, with a well-defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of enhancing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing fundamental rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures by both sides, which are not conducive to a peaceful resolution.

contributed in any way to the escalation of tensions in the region, and even less to the effective pursuit of a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

It is time for the international community to say enough. It is time for Europe and the Arab League to drive the search for a lasting solution, with wisdom, presenting viable solutions, without delay and with definitive deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let us start with Jerusalem. Why not revive the initial idea of a corpus separatum administered by the UN, which would obviously serve as the capital of both states?
Borders. Let's start with those of 1967.
Exchange plots of land when possible and coherent.
Ensure the defense of Israel, an obviously unavoidable issue for the Jewish people, for example, by deploying blue helmets with American, European, and Islamic forces along the Jordan River.
Refugees, numbering around 4.8 million, have the right to their dignity and to a future connected to a land, preferably their own.

but it is not exclusively an Israeli or Palestinian problem, it is also ours, it is the problem of neighboring Arab countries, of the Arab community in general, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
colonies, and their expansion must be ended, which is non-negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and reflects hypocrisy and bad faith in a declaration of availability for immediate negotiations.

Above all, we want negotiations in good faith, committed, with a deadline for their conclusion, after which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to adopt a different approach.

Thank you, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has already been mentioned here, and we all share, and I share to a great extent, what my colleagues who have just spoken have said.
I will not refer to this in particular; I will mention another, more overlooked situation, which is that of citizens who were welcomed into Tunisian families' homes.

And this is one of the situations that should shame us even more, because let's take notice: Tunisia, in a time of crisis, knew how to be supportive. Europe does not know how to be supportive and is not undergoing a transition to democracy; it did not know how to be supportive, it did not know how to receive.
I find it, in fact, shameful that we can count in the hundreds the number of refugees received in Europe.
Many of these people, contrary to what has been said, cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the infrastructure level, and implications for the reception capacity of these countries.
And that is why, Madam Commissioner, I am very moved by the appeal you make, and I say this not ironically, but seriously. But please, what about the Commission?
And Europe!
What can it do?
How does Europe live so comfortably with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Commissioner.
It cannot continue like this.

Mr. President, I would, of course, like to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all European parliamentarians and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union whom we represent here.

And, having said that, I would like to state that we now expect the Commission to take a very, very determined action with the Council so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but immediate signals are needed.

And, therefore, without prejudice to us all already beginning to think about a treaty amendment that provides the political translation for the entire project we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something needs to be done immediately.

This set of measures and, perhaps, an agreement among the States, what I have been calling a kind of parasocial agreement that goes beyond treaties and that can, from this moment on, put all these ideas into action.
Congratulations on your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and leave here today with renewed determination.

Mr. President, the crisis that the European Union is going through has had severe consequences in all member states, and thousands of workers have been affected by the dismissals caused by globalization and the crisis.
We must affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and state that Europe should assist Member States in maintaining a high employment rate and combating unemployment.
Rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a top priority goal.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has resorted to it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalization Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to support thousands of workers through vocational training measures, business creation aids, and recruitment incentives.
This proposal is positive because it will enable Member States to request the intervention of this Fund to support workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic and financial crisis.
