We support the extension of the deadline and understand that it should be the Member States most affected by the crisis that have greater and easier access to this Globalization and Crisis Support Fund.
Thank you, President. I congratulate the Polish Presidency and also Mr. Commissioner Ali Ren, just to say that I consider that...
And today, building upon and developing what was achieved in the State of the Union address, a very, very significant step was taken towards resolving the issues of the eurozone crisis.
because the Commission has undertaken here its commitment to use its power of initiative and to work with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and is the only way we have at this moment to resolve the eurozone crisis.
There is no possibility of resolving this in the short term with only an intergovernmental approach. Therefore, it is necessary for the States, the state governments, to give...
commission the tools and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to put it into practice, execute and develop this roadmap that it has presented here.
But I do not want to fail to mention that this is not incompatible with our doing so simultaneously, with our developing at the same time our capacity to amend the treaties.

I am also convinced that, in the medium term, the treaties need to be amended, but even then, we must do so with the aim of strengthening the Commission, of giving it more power and a stronger position.

It is through the strengthening of the community method, now in the short term and later with a change in the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve greater integration and a solution for the seventeen countries of the euro area and for the twenty-seven countries of the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce that as one of the measures, banks that do not meet capital requirements must present plans to obtain them and, if they fail to do so, they should then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not but agree with this presentation made by Mr. President.
Just this week, we witnessed what happened with Dexia Bank, and a few months ago, a director of this bank received a bonus of 600,000 euros for his supposedly wonderful management, as we are aware.
But to be serious, the President of the Commission has to call the governments and present the full package. And the full package is what contains the essentials.
The essential point is that taxpayer money should be matched by a credit policy aimed at growth.
The crucial point is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, notably in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or more accurately, in three years, this is the second time we are being asked to save the banks with taxpayer money, with money from the unemployed.
the banks that also save the economy, aiding job creation.
Mr. President, High Representative, there are times when I think we need little more than to take stock, and this seems to be one of those times.
And it seems to me that this is because we always follow the rhythm of events and the response from one event to another, and we lose sight of the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case in itself and each country we are discussing here is a specific instance, but, forgive me for saying, High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize what criteria the European Union has employed to act upon each case.
I fear that we are often hostages to the interests of the countries of the European Union, on the part of some of these countries of the European Union and not all of them.
And that is why we so often use the expression "double standards" in this House, and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions, sometimes it is not. Sometimes interference goes as far as the bomb, as was the case in Libya. Other times, there is complete silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi forces.

Saudi Arabia. And, Madam Baroness, let me say, I have been studying all the dossiers closely, and I have yet to see a single statement from the European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi Arabian military forces.

These are death sentences, endless violence, doctors and nurses condemned to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were allegedly opposed to the regime and not aiding the wounded who needed them.
With regard to the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain and the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the Saleh regime, we have had far more silence than action.

I am not in favor of interference, nor have I ever been, but I fear we may place ourselves in an uncomfortable position, the position viewed from the outside, Baroness, which is, instead of aiding development, aspirations...

democratic and revolutionary movements of the peoples in Arab countries, instead of aiding the First Arab Spring, what we do is prevent its extension, whether by excess or by deficiency, and I do not think we should bear that sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yamita activist can serve as a signal that our side is the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, this is a good report from colleague Casa.
First and foremost, one must ask why the VAT (Value Added Tax) in the European Union should be revised.
Firstly, the need to align it with the single market.
The more VAT rates and varieties there are, the less fluid the market will be.
An VAT reform favors e-commerce, focuses competition on the value and base price of goods and services, and not on tax differences.
fights fraud and ensures much-needed trust, especially in cross-border transactions, improves the economy of SMEs, and reduces administrative burdens.
What other measures regarding Youth are already underway in the single market that could be associated with VAT?
Firstly, a simple, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism, the seventh measure of the single market.
Measure 5, concerning services, highlights the need to revise legislation on standardization and the implementation of the directive on...
the new measure aimed at removing tax obstacles and explicitly reviewing the VAT system and VAT equalization in online and face-to-face trade, which we all experience when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two fundamental orders of reasons.
first and foremost, the economic crisis
More revenue is needed, including, in some countries, potentially reducing labor contributions to promote economic development, shifting this burden to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressures is the aging population, demographic aging, and the trend towards shifting from indirect to direct taxation due to the reduction in the tax base population.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, in these reforms, we have to reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the range of variation in the standard VAT rate so that we can all understand better.
Greater transparency is required in defining the reduced VAT rate and its scope, along with a clear and widely disseminated list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, fully aware that each exemption brings with it a train of small or large-scale frauds.
Finally, to welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Madam President, I thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report she has prepared.

Certainly, the advantages of public procurement are well-known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States hinder competitiveness.
The dichotomy between the quality of prices and the complexity of laws and procedures is evident.
It is crucial to examine existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has been successful and has streamlined public procurement processes.
An effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling public deficit and fostering growth.
To achieve this, it should have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and uphold social and environmental values.

That is why I express satisfaction with the intentions that Commissioner Barnier has presented to us here for the revision of public procurement, still this year, as one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act. Thank you.
Congratulate colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the realm of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.
Unfortunately, the targets set by the European Union, 50% of decisions by electronic procedure by 2010, were missed, with an average value barely reaching 5%.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are highly evident and have been outlined above. It allows for the replacement of costly access processes with a simple consultation of the electronic platform, thereby reducing many costs for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

small and medium-sized enterprises. Online advertising and the ease of receiving legal documents increase the number of suppliers, enhancing competition and enabling better purchasing decisions. It streamlines the process of awarding public contracts...

Easier and more flexible, it simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thus facilitating participation in the public contract market of these important drivers of the economy.
In this regard, we welcome and encourage the European Commission's efforts to strengthen mechanisms to make electronic public procurement an increasingly widespread reality. Thank you very much.

We are living through decisive hours for the fate of Europe. And while the situation has swiftly evolved, in plain sight, from a Greek or Portuguese problem to a major European issue, the truth is that the inadequacy and delay of the proposed solutions have yielded no effectiveness in stemming the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The pursuit of state-specific solutions, to the detriment of truly European ones, allowed markets to continue speculating on sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and rhythms.
It is absolutely impossible for some states to achieve their goals through measures of unimaginable brutality being imposed on individuals, businesses, and the public sector.

It is absolutely imperative to find a common solution, as has already been done for the risk of European sovereign debt, that alleviates market pressure and speculation, and provides time for the essential adjustments to be made.
Without this, what we will have at the end are countries that will continue without the means to pay their creditors, destroyed economies, and a great deal of suffering.

to the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I would also like to thank the rapporteurs from the partners of the four committees involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 compromises, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest generated by the topic of new skills and jobs.
Ultimately, it is a matter of preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the coming decade.
The key strategy in drafting the report was to rephrase common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I believe that this goal has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the fragilities of the European economic and social model, as well as undone much of the progress achieved in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, there are nearly 23 million people without jobs.
Youth unemployment is even more alarming. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21%, representing more than double the overall unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States, unemployment rates vary according to qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find employment more easily.
We also know that in the near future, the demands in terms of skills, competencies, and qualifications will increase across all types and levels of professions.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. Firstly, job creation. Secondly, the need to develop and maintain competitiveness.
Subsequently, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty in finding individuals with the appropriate skills to fill job openings.

This report thus has a dual objective. Firstly, to emphasize the need to act swiftly to address skills gaps in Europe. The second objective is to better anticipate the skills needs of the labor market.

To achieve this, several measures stand out. Firstly, to ensure the availability of a qualified workforce, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as competencies in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I have mentioned, skill requirements should be identified early on, with a minimum timeframe of 10 years.
Today, we understand the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications.
Subsequently, there should be an increase in participation in lifelong learning and vocational retraining, as well as a reduction in school dropout rates.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications, and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that should exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
Internships should be of high quality and supervised by tutors to ensure they lead to employment opportunities and prevent any potential exploitation of interns.
Special emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we need to create jobs.
And small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role here in achieving this goal.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, hence the need for coordination of social security systems to ensure that workers' acquired rights are safeguarded, particularly the portability of pensions.

Lastly, the issue of labor market flexibility. To enhance the functioning of the labor market, the rules of flexicurity should be tailored to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. I begin by thanking all the colleagues who contributed to this lively debate.
All colleagues had very useful interventions and contributed to a highly constructive discussion on an ambitious agenda at a time when we are facing a severe crisis.
In fact, this discussion is taking place on the eve of a European Council which will reveal whether there is political will to overcome the difficulties we are facing, or not.

policy for a deeper coordination among us in economic terms and whether there is indeed a harmonized and unified will to move forward with the ambition outlined in this agenda. In other words, to have
New jobs in the coming decade, jobs that will give hope to young people who are currently unemployed and those who are graduating, hope in an inclusive labor market that meets their...

ambition for dignification through work, and who also have the opportunity to be in a state of perpetual dynamism to keep up with the challenges of a globalized economy, with a dynamic that has no parallel in recent generations.

Therefore, our ambition is truly to achieve job creation and economic growth, not only to address the needs of those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to accommodate those who are about to enter the labor market.

response to the major challenges ahead with the green economy, with health services, with transportation services, and with housing, which require from all of us a different perspective, an intelligent vision, and an inclusive view of the labor market.
thank you all.

Marisa Matias. Thank you very much, Madam President. What we were told today in the Council's statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in the context of the European semester. But what we are discussing is a political issue, and the question I raise is whether political coordination can exist without democracy.
Where, ultimately, lies the scrutiny of the European Parliament?
Where is the scrutiny of National Parliaments on their major budgetary choices?

But, if the issue were technical, as has been stated here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions of the four countries on the waiting list, namely France, Italy, Hungary, and Spain. It did not do the same for the countries under rescue programs.
Therefore, what model of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to offer opinions on Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to offer opinions on Germany?
And, Commissioner, I merely ask you to pay attention to this. No democratic legitimacy issue is resolved by asking Members to go and consult the information on the internet.
This is an issue of information exclusion, not democratic exclusion, which is what we are discussing here.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Ardenne, on the quality and timeliness of this report, as well as Commissioner Andor on the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that requires effective and swift action to stem the rise of this phenomenon, which currently affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The severe crisis we are going through has exacerbated this situation and made the times we live in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor stated.
The number of people unemployed continues to rise, and we all know that joblessness is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, determination, and considerable effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
Therefore, I warmly welcome the initiative of the Platform against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
President, access to the internet should today be considered as a new fundamental right of citizens, and not merely as a mere object of commerce.
Essential things depend on it, such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that restrict free choice and the possibility of easily changing suppliers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that comprehensive and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of internet use is not exclusive to political regimes that fear their own people.
It can also occur as a result of economic choices, by offering privileges to potential clients and less equitable treatment to customers who are not as profitable.
It is for all these reasons that I support the Parliament in clearly siding with the neutrality of the internet and in defending its character of total openness.
Let's speak the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to get out of the crisis, and the situation is worsening day by day.
In place of healing, we have created two fatal vicious circles.
The first between banks and states.
In Europe, it is now easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state than that of a major bank, yet there remains an expectation that banks will finance states and that states will bail out their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must proceed with European legislation that protects taxpayers from banking crises.
but it is also vital to protect the states' debt from speculators' attacks.

And, for this, it is urgent and already late to prepare coordinated emissions of sovereign debt, whether called eurobonds or stability bonds, and to guarantee them through robust community-based, not intergovernmental, instruments.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle arises from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically incorrect.

She ignores the essential fact that a single market and currency, constructed by political choice among unequals, necessarily exacerbates competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And that is what needs to be addressed in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompoy, through sanctions that promote wage and income suppression via one country's control over another.
previously, through a commitment, Mr. Commissioner, from countries with surpluses as well as those with deficits, in order to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
The tensions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and another form we cannot account for.

Many thanks, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. The integrated maritime policy promotes a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas, and coasts, from a global and coherent perspective of all European marine-related policies.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach entails the interaction of European maritime-related policies and calls for improved governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past few years through the various initiatives funded in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy should, therefore, continue to benefit from adequate funding during the coming years of the current financial programming period.
In this regard, I advocate adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, but also to support the establishment of a stable framework for the objectives of this program.
Policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance issues are, for obvious reasons, matters of particular interest to certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The OCTs are regions that, with the exception of French Guiana, being small in size, depend on a limited number of economic activities, and where activities related to the sea and fisheries play a particularly important role.
Moreover, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.

The Outermost Regions (ORs) account for over half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 out of 25 million square kilometers. Together with coastal regions, they are crucial for the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.

A program such as the one outlined in the integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions, emphasizing the transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is, therefore, necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also, and above all, for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
Failing to take advantage of the opportunity, when discussing integrated maritime policy, to emphasize the immense potential that the Atlantic and insular dimensions hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, as Europe's western maritime border, also connects it to North and South America and Africa, providing a strategic dimension for Europe that is essential in shaping a maritime policy with a forward-looking perspective.

It is with a view to the future that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the coordination of maritime activities, must place at the forefront of its priorities the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension, based on science and technology.

The exploration of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, deep sea, and marine sediments represents a new frontier with vast potential in biotechnology and mineral resources, holding incalculable value for the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the Azores' privileged position and the excellence of its oceanographic department to establish a Deep Sea Observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is incorrect, the remedies do not work.
And in the case of the eurozone, the excessive remedies have led even to the brink of death.
The successive miracle solutions that were proposed were equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilization Fund, the successive tightening measures of the Stability and Growth Pact, the Troika's revenues in the low-program countries.
Blind austerity without growth sparked a recessionary wave among fully interconnected economies, which thus became contaminated by bankruptcies and unemployment.
And into the hands of the markets, that is, the rating agencies and speculators, governments are falling one after another, and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Amending the treaties now is yet another step on this disastrous path, with an additional complication. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty, placing countries under the control of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to amend the treaties.
In this emergency we find ourselves in, two decisions must be made.
Firstly, it is necessary to materialize a genuine agenda for growth and sustained cohesion.
Where is the Agenda 2020?
Where is the stimulus budget?
Where are the much-vaunted projects, the Project Bonds, for Europe's structural investments?
And, secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.

Of course, eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency situation we find ourselves in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends sovereign debt against speculators.
not in a shy manner, but with a definitive, decided stance, as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that sustains it.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties; what is needed is political will and European conviction.
We will revisit the treaty once we have drawn all the lessons from the current crisis. And there are certainly many lessons to be learned, but this is not the time for that. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner Dali, the first Single Market Forum, an idea stemming from the Greco report, took place in Kraków.
was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional, and local authorities, as well as civil society.
We have a roadmap outlined in the Commission's communication of April 12 with the 12 levers.
needs to be enshrined in law, along with the strategy for the other thirty-eight priorities identified in the act for the single market.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it needs to be stimulated and nurtured.

The single market is not merely a buying and selling operation; it encompasses horizontal policies such as health, social and consumer protection, labor law, the environment, and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should, therefore, become a flagship event of the European Union, with an annual occurrence and a diverse and increasingly engaged audience.
Mr. President, I believe we are at a time for taking stock of these crisis policies, austerity measures that have affected so many countries, as well as the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have caused so much social upheaval.
and has generated social confusion not only in the countries in greatest distress, in the countries of the South, not just in the so-called PIGS, but also in other European contexts.
Just last week, Portugal witnessed the largest general strike in its history, encompassing both the public and private sectors. This was a strike that took to the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we find that we have witnessed the largest strike ever, especially considering that people also took to the streets there, as they did in Portugal.
And we expect a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove and the people's turnout in the streets, is that the causes and problems we have been facing are common, and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in financial markets and the growing inability to secure essential financing for the operations of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are otherwise healthy, driving them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for rigorous budget discipline, deep restructurings, and enhanced economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that policies aimed at employment and growth are needed, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debts, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will precipitate itself.
Therefore, now more than ever, more than a revision of the treaties, we need a strong and confident intervention from the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. We are all gathered here today, united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day, and this assessment of the resolution and communication from 2009 is crucial.
It is fundamental to precisely address things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to be done.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European Economic Area. A 2010 report speaks of over 25,000 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about more than one hundred thousand new cases.
And if we think there are things that cannot get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues I want to make very clear here has to do with the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
And this disinvestment has had a very serious impact on areas that are fundamental to the fight against HIV-AIDS.
It is for this reason, Commissioner, that I believe the Commission has a crucial role to play in urging Member States to fulfill their obligations in these areas.

A second issue also relates to the increase in discrimination, also evidenced by the economic and social crisis, discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs due to being importers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for all, regardless of gender, age, or the region where they live.
And I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Draghi.
We are facing exceptional and dramatic circumstances, which demand decisive and urgent action.

The spiral between sovereign debt and bank debt must be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the countries of the eurozone and the euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report we will adopt, Tremosa and Vassal, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the euro area, create eurobonds and a European treasury, but all this takes time.
At this moment, we are facing an emergency and, in this context, the sole solution lies in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, you should not be inhibited in your intervention and action by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to manage inflation.
At a time like this, there is no doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Draghi.
The European Neighborhood Policy already explicitly included the positions that the European Parliament has been taking.

And it was with great satisfaction that we saw a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been advocating in this House incorporated into the subsequent communications of the Commission and the Council.

I would like to express my gratitude, in fact, for the excellent and ongoing collaboration and coordination we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and Commissioner Stefan Fule, as well as their offices.
first and foremost, through the upgrade achieved in our relationship with neighboring peoples.

By prioritizing relations with the general population and civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively based on the universal values that we uphold and share.
I emphasize, however, that the European Union does not intend to impose a pre-defined model or formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers' money, we should give more to those who are doing more to align with the values we believe in.
This principle signifies that the faster a country progresses with its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is, therefore, correct, fair, and consistent.
What this obviously means is that we also anticipate the hypothesis that there may be cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighborhood policy now revolves around upholding shared values and a commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law, and good governance.
But this search implies greater accountability.

Our partners are called upon to take on more responsibility in the process. Therefore, we advocate for the principles of greater differentiation, increased conditionality, and the concept of more for more.

By adopting a bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies, which we refer to as approaching our partners from the ground up and custom-made policies, we enhance the effectiveness of development and institutional capacity.

institutional building that we so desperately want to defend, and which lies at the foundation of the rule of law and the democratic process. We wish to see it implemented as swiftly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give a voice to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that align with our values, by supporting organized movements striving for positive and democratic change in their countries.
countries, enhancing the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, be it of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.
etc., with fair elections, with the fight against corruption, a rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection, and resource efficiency.
The severe economic and social problems facing our neighbors also require immediate action.
It is evident that, without our concrete help, the ongoing democratic processes may fail.
These were the ideas we have always advocated for the future European neighborhood policy.
These are the proposals contained in the report we are bringing to your vote.
It is time to act now.
For our part, we will remain vigilant and exercise the new monitoring and oversight powers now vested in the European Parliament.
In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur, and friend Marek Sivic. I express my special recognition for his remarkable work on the eastern dimension of the neighborhood policy.
also to the Shadow and opinion rapporteurs and to all of you for the numerous suggestions put forward in the amendments you tabled, which I believe have enhanced our work.
And a final word to the Secretariat of the Commission and to the political advisors for the excellent support work I benefited from.
The European neighborhood policy without including the outermost regions as active frontiers of Europe in various parts of the world.
As external borders, the outermost regions convey our values of democracy, peace, and respect for human rights and fundamental rights to the third countries in these regions.
Regions such as the French ultra-peripheral ones have an absolute need for greater integration within their geographical areas.
Remote from the EU's internal market, this integration is crucial for their development and represents a vast potential for deepening the neighborhood policy with neighboring third countries.

The neighborhood policy requires a new impetus, one that also leverages the privileged historical-cultural relations that the outermost regions of the Azores, Madeira, and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
A more active role in support of the European Union can and should be played by these regions within the framework of a new European neighborhood policy.

Thank you, Mr. President. It was last September that, after in-depth debate, in which I also engaged as the Socialist Group's spokesperson on this matter, we organized meetings and discussions with European, national, and regional organizations related to...

For retailers, manufacturers, and farmers, the Parliament adopted the Bouvé report, which includes an exhaustive set of recommendations to the European Commission aimed at ensuring fair income for farmers and improving the functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, in fact, the Commission and the Parliament have been producing communications, reports, recommendations, and establishing high-level forums and groups to address this serious issue, without any practical changes being made, aside from increased awareness.

We return to the subject, and it is necessary to state it without hesitation. A significant portion of the problems faced by farmers stem from highly penalizing behaviors imposed primarily by operators in modern distribution.
The problems are more than identified.
What has been lacking in the Commission and among the Member States is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to see losses for farmers and consumers.
to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, he is, above all, dangerous.
First, because it reinforces with more punishments and strict rules a recipe that does not work.
The recursive spiral is unleashed.
Who can trust a doctor who cannot distinguish between weight loss and anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more he insists on the medicine, while openly discussing the likelihood of their death.
How many more countries need to fall into recession before the Commission and the Council realize that the diagnosis is incorrect?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million and 700 thousand are unemployed.
Nearly six million young people have no hope of finding employment.
Will the Council and the Commission not realize that ignoring this fact, failing to provide an adequate response, reveals an autism and insensitivity that are politically explosive?
Let's be clear.
The great recession is not a fate, it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. However, it must not be one of words, but of action.
Where are the Project Bonds to finance European investment?
where is the reinforcement of the European budget with the tax on speculative financial products.
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates imposed by the markets, driving them to ruin?
Citizens demand actions, not words, but competent actions. Thank you very much.
Many thanks, Madam President. The Commission and governments now promise to reprogramme structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.

However, it is worth recalling that, towards the end of last year, the Commission also decided on the suspension of the allocation of structural funds to countries that do not meet or have not met the deficit or debt targets.
It doesn't take much genius to realize that either the promise is fulfilled or the punishment is carried out, but both at the same time is not possible.
And that is why, Commissioner, I would like to ask you a very direct question. Has the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds been maintained, frozen, or annulled?
In other words, can Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and other countries still access funds they are entitled to if they do not meet the objectives being imposed by the Commission and by you?
Respond, Commissioner, please. The thing is, in Portugal, we are very tired of promises, you see?
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The proposal made by President Barroso to reallocate available structural funds to support our SMEs.
and stimulating employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies facing severe austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the agreement on external intervention and the significant financing difficulties faced by the economy, and particularly our small and medium-sized enterprises, through the banking system, this proposal takes on special importance for regions such as the Azores. These regions, despite their high absorption and good use of funds, are embedded within a recessionary context.

Here you can achieve a real opportunity to boost your economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our best-prepared young generation ever in providing the best response to growth and employment with these funds...
three options.
What we need to know, Commissioner, is how, in practice, we will access these funds and how our regions will participate in their reprogramming.

President, Commissioner, the milk package presented here as an instrument for organizing the sector contains positive and important elements such as the strengthening of the role of producer organizations and interprofessional organizations, and contractual aspects that, in some Member States, together with the trainers, may leave us...

However, this falls far short of the tools the sector needs to thrive in the coming years, within the framework of an agriculture that we want to see in Europe, one that has access to a fair distribution of value in the food chain, and that does not transform into an agriculture of large, intensive farms concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving self-regulation in the relationship between sector actors is desirable, believing that this alone is sufficient is a serious mistake that could exclude thousands of dairy producers, dozens of regions, and even some countries from dairy farming.
The debate on the regulation of the dairy sector from the perspective of economic, social, environmental, and territorial sustainability remains to be done.
And we cannot abandon the milk quota system without having guaranteed genuine tools for managing supply.
Many thanks, Mr. President, Ms. Commissioner. From May 2010 to this day, we have seen how an issue that seemed manageable has worsened in an uncontrolled manner.

It is true that the fight against the crisis triggered by financial markets has exacerbated the indebtedness of euro area countries, and that the most fragile ones have become particularly vulnerable.
However, is it possible that countries sharing the same currency be left to the mercy of financial operators and those who profit from betting on the likelihood of eurozone countries going bankrupt?
The terrible consequences of the Commission's inability to respond have created problems that are now undeniable.
The speculative interest rates imposed on individual countries rendered any strategy to exit the crisis unviable.
The subsequent exacerbation of the country's economic problem justifies a new hike in interest rates until the complete cutoff of credit kills a country's economy, and contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long advocated for a common form of sovereign debt management, subject to stringent but clear rules.
We welcome the fact that the Commission has finally produced a Green Paper on the subject, what has been called...

It is now clear that without some form of such obligations, properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, the so-called protection barriers, these firewalls for sovereign debt, do not exist. And until they do exist, the euro is in danger, as is Europe.

In the resolution that this Parliament overwhelmingly approved regarding the new Treaty, it was made absolutely clear that it is not acceptable to continue imposing further fiscal stability rules, budgetary discipline, and sanctions on eurozone countries without taking concrete and urgent steps towards the solidary management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will need to evolve in parallel.
That is what we expect from the Commission, and it is too late now.

I would like to think that this House of European Democracy will unanimously repudiate the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the murder of their own people, which we witness daily, powerless to intervene.
Because it is important that Europe can speak with one voice about the significance of values of respect for human life in the face of indiscriminate and globally orchestrated massacres.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime by implementing new restrictive measures.
The killings must stop, and this is non-negotiable.
insist on dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria requires a transition period and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the implementation of more restrictive measures against the Syrian regime is not effective if all countries do not row in the same direction. And, unfortunately, this has not been the case.
In addition to thousands of deaths and their resolutions shamefully rejected in the United Nations Security Council,
We continue to condemn the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in their unbelievable support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains the same. A desperate and cornered power regime continues to govern a country, and we, the international community, remain powerless to stop the genocide of a people.
We are already far behind in hardening the action of the European Union and the international community.
We must provide more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and in its intentions to deploy a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must support the Red Crescent's work without reservation in its efforts to minimize the suffering of populations.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings with a view to punishing those responsible for the crimes being perpetrated against humanity.
and as a means of pressuring countries that have continued to support Assad, also prohibit European Union trade with all Russian or Chinese companies that have commercial relations.
