Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Madam Commissioner, to discuss this issue of such importance.
In fact, we are dealing with central issues related to data protection and, above all, in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

And data protection is, in fact, one of the sensitive areas that has generated so much controversy and, in my opinion, should continue to do so. Because we are talking about what could be the clash between the...

rights and guarantees, the protection of European citizens who are safeguarded by European legislation and then find themselves overridden when the legislation of other countries overlays European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
It is sensitive because there is a breach and a doubt in what is a contract that, for all intents and purposes, exists between European citizens and European institutions.
When they provide their personal data, individuals do so with the understanding that it will be protected by entities and European institutions and will not be distributed for other purposes.

And, therefore, there is a breach of trust here, which is a complex issue to manage. Moreover, it is a serious and precarious situation because the European Union ultimately transfers personal data to third countries, thereby breaking the seal of trust that is established.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health issues, to other matters such as those mentioned regarding companies.

that require data, and I am specifically referring, for example, to the case of the United States, which systematically requests data from the European Union. This occurs when citizens assume they are conceding their data, and, as mentioned, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, which results in a breach of trust.
Therefore, I also want to tell you, Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic, for various reasons, but I will always side with the manifestations of the citizens.

who wish to protect their personal data. And if there are demonstrations that they feel compelled to make because European institutions are not complying, I believe we should stand with the citizens, not on the opposing side.

It is almost a kind of betrayal that is being carried out. And that is why we ask you this question, these issues we raise with you, Commissioner, to clarify once and for all, because no community is built with destruction as its foundation or basis.

a decline in the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And, in this regard, Commissioner, please tell us to what extent we can ensure that European legislation takes precedence over the legislation of third countries?
For it is true that European legislation overlays the legislation of the countries of the 27 Member States of the European Union, and citizens thereby relinquish their rights.
Why, in this area of sovereignty, at many times, could we accept that other countries, such as the United States, subsequently override European legislation, which overrides national legislation?
It is necessary for this to be clarified because it is indeed very sensitive, it is serious, and it is an issue we must take into consideration.

And lastly, Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing to ensure that this does not happen, to prevent it from being a recurring issue, and to safeguard the personal data of all citizens.

of companies and various sectors referenced in these issues are, in fact, data that people can trust, protected under what we safeguard. By this, I mean that I do not even advocate for all stored information to be stored, but that is a separate discussion.

With regard to this matter, as it is a serious issue and one that is pressing in terms of citizens' rights, I would appreciate if you could provide these clarifications so that we can all be more assured. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, I would essentially like to say that from the upcoming Council, we expect a major economic decision for the countries under aid, closely related to the issue of structural funds.
It is necessary to flexibilize the structural funds.
There are many that remain to be used, a large portion of which have been utilized solely for large-scale infrastructures.
must be focused on competitiveness, on small and medium-sized enterprises, and on revitalizing the economy.
The only investment that countries like Greece, like Portugal, like Ireland, and like others can have at this time is that which arises from these structural funds.
It also left a political note for all Union politicians, those who are acting in good faith in the European process.
When discussing these topics, it is essential to respect and exercise great care regarding national identities and the Member States.
politicians, sometimes with good intentions, but not all have risen to the challenge of strictly respecting each Member State's national identity.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I greet the rapporteurs and the... But I would like to say that enough is enough of pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the first results on macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil begins to lift on why, in the European Union and particularly in the euro area, some countries are growing while others are fatally declining.

Europe is losing competitiveness in external markets, and this agenda needs to be revised because it is through this that much of the insufficient internal growth passes. But, focused on the internal market,
Four countries, including Germany, accumulate successive surpluses year after year, while twenty other countries, I repeat, twenty, accumulate deficits year after year as well.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases in an unsustainable manner.
Of course, this process has to be controlled,
Of course, discipline is required.
But it is important to ask today, is the solution of crushing the most vulnerable with recessionary policies the only possible solution in this context?
Is it acceptable for some winners within the internal market to continue engaging in tax competition?

Can the largest European economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while suitable for its own economy, capture in its favor the bulk of the gains from the internal market?
Can the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessionary policies that tighten the economies of the most vulnerable, while debating?
openly discussing the possibility of bankruptcy for sovereign states in the eurozone, when they know that circuit breakers have never left the file of intentions?
Are the Commission and the Council fully aware of the politically and economically explosive risk that this speech poses to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to radically revise the recipes.
but for that, there must be political will.
Until that will does not exist, out of respect for citizens, let us stop saying that we advocate for growth and employment, because it is not true.
and citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Many thanks, Mr. President. I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.
To say that we are living through the most severe financial, economic, and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model is now a common refrain.
It is never excessive to underscore that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic highs, demanding that the fight against unemployment be the top priority.
Youth unemployment is dramatic. In my country, Portugal, more than one in every three young people are looking for employment and have no prospects of finding it.
Our citizens are disillusioned.
It is urgent to restore confidence.
After years of imprudent management of public finances, it is time to adopt budgetary consolidation reforms and get the accounts in order.
But we must not delude ourselves, austerity without economic growth is merely a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European design.

Measures to ensure that young people do not remain more than four months without receiving an offer of employment or training, as well as to reduce the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
One year ago, we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in quick succession.
Today we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
Honoring the victims means telling them that we have learned the lesson, we must learn to deal with natural disasters, and with nuclear ones, we have the obligation to prevent them.
But, unfortunately, this does not seem to be the truth.
One year after Fukushima, and new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
One year after Fukushima, and new nuclear power plants continue to be planned.
Japan, unfortunately, has the memory of enduring tragedies, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of an enduring tragedy, Chernobyl.
Fukushima compels us, for all these reasons, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate on nuclear energy.
One year ago, nuclear energy was unquestioned by the Japanese. Today, two-thirds of Japanese people do not want it.
They know it costs lives, they know that this cost is priceless. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear power is a policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe as well, we have a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and yet nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320,000 refugees in Japan. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous. What was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation. It is the ruin of contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited as other ruins are visited, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin. But, nevertheless, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization, and the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
that chose to include in its development model a deadly technology.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, just as in Europe, many citizens have decided to create movements to say farewell to nuclear (power).
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is a non-existent entity. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests that...
can simulate what happened in Fukushima. And that's why we know that energy policies are national.
As already mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
And these are, indeed, the numbers of an epidemic.
And that is why I believe it is also justified to adopt a specific resolution on diabetes, all the more so as this is the first time that this Parliament has devoted itself to this issue.
It is the result of collective work and it is a work that does not negate the work done so far on chronic diseases; on the contrary, it strengthens our ability to intervene collectively.

We have approximately 325,000 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, and failures of vital organs.
And in light of these data, we have two options, in my view.
The first point is to argue that it is not that serious, that we can live well with it, and that each government should take care of itself.
The second point is that the absence of a European strategy in this field is part of the problem.
I understand that, from this side, we have a lot to do.
And there is much to be done in early diagnosis, coordination, and investment in research.
And that is why this resolution holds value as a starting point and a joint effort in this direction. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I essentially wanted to draw attention to was to congratulate the Council on its results.
not because the measures are ideal, but because they are the possible measures.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.

Many states have been making a tremendous effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been undertaken in some states due to the inducement of the European Union.
It is crucial for them to regain their credibility in international markets, and it is essential for their long-term growth prospects.
With these guarantees that states have been providing, among which the Portuguese state stands out, in terms of achieving fiscal consolidation and budgetary consolidation, I am...
Convinced, also with the new treaty signed between the 25, that we will be in a position to seriously relaunch growth in the upcoming steps of the European Council.
But it is only with this trust that is being gradually generated that this growth must be achieved.
And so, I say, solidarity from the richest towards the poorest is important, but also from the poorest towards the richest, providing these guarantees.
Mr. President, I would like to essentially say that it is with great joy that we observe steps being taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, Spain, or Greece, which were nations that endured dictatorships and faced a series of severe problems, demonstrates that European integration was the means to solidify democracy.
And, therefore, Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would like, in any case, to offer here a note that differs somewhat from the one presented by my colleagues.

I am aware of and welcome great concern for minorities, but it is essential not to forget the Serbian majority. It is crucial that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a place in full right.
This must not be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia. And, therefore, while we strongly emphasize the rights of minorities, which must be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, their identity, and their full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their own state and their own national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Portugal voted last week on the treaty, or rather, the budget ultimatum, which, in fact, is not a European treaty. It is important to mention this.

The favorable vote of the government parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good, sycophantic student, who does not think and obeys bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to shift from a dangerously violent abstention to a tracking vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Assembly of the Republic, of Portugal, the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating one of its most important functions for which the people elected it: deciding the country's annual budget.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, yet another. It is a blow in which the power of money becomes increasingly out of reach of the citizens' vote.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that voting is no longer possible? Thank you.
Budget consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, each day there are fewer individuals bearing a heavier burden.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, while there is a significant and disproportionate level of tax evasion and avoidance.
The Group of European Socialists wanted to know how much this tax evasion and avoidance was worth in the 27 countries, and it is worth one million million euros, in English, one trillion euros.
This is more than the countries of the European Union spend on health.

This means a volume such that, if we were to spend only one-fifth of this amount on investment, investment in Europe would rise from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are, therefore, talking about an exceptionally high value.

And the purpose of the resolution we are about to adopt, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to expedite concrete action against tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for tax cooperation within the European Union, tax cooperation with our neighboring countries, especially Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not on a country-by-country basis bilaterally.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a major partner in the international context.
Europe has an obligation, within the G20 framework, to clearly advocate for a joint fight against fraud and tax evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens. Therefore, my final words in this debate are to encourage the Commission and the Council to initiate effective action against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Nibler on her excellent work and to note the coincidence that, on Europe Day, which we celebrate today, we are debating and will tomorrow approve measures that respond to the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.

What this regulation aims to address is the imposition of limits on mobile phone charges levied on European consumers when roaming, with the ultimate goal of abolishing roaming fees within the European area by 2016.
Our citizens now benefit from a significant reduction in prices for calls, SMS, and data.
If nowadays there are operators charging 3 euros per mega, from July the maximum price they will be able to charge is 70 cents per mega, decreasing to 20 cents in 2014.
Regarding received calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner stated, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: improved quality of information for consumers.
Starting from the summer, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices applied when they travel outside the European Union as well.
Until now, the obligation was limited to within the European space.
Third advantage, the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer may, if they wish, have two contracts: one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad, while retaining the same mobile number and receiving only one bill.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be given the possibility to contract with any European operator that offers them the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
Madam President, in February 2009 this Parliament adopted a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.
There were clean energy, transport, new technology, and innovation projects, and even at that time, the role of the European Investment Bank and the structural funds was being leveraged.
More than three years later, we have been able to produce the Six-Pack, the Europlus Pact, the Fiscal Compact, and the Two-Pack, all of them filled with reinforced discipline and sanctions.

However, meanwhile, as unemployment, particularly among youth, reaches alarming levels, the European economy is falling into recession, and more than seven of its member states are experiencing negative growth.
And, meanwhile, while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to bring down the castle, the agenda for relaunching seems to have been forgotten.
At this moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is no longer to assign it a sense of urgency, but rather a sense of emergency in a situation that threatens to explode.
It is urgent to intervene in a set of pillars.
Firstly, it is essential that this European Marshall Plan be established with investment that promotes growth, employment, and convergence.
Project Bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us prepare, at the very least, to coordinate sovereign debt emissions and jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Third point, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to effectively function as true firewalls in the defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was massively transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks must reach businesses.
It is a billion euros that is retained in the banking system, while thousands of viable businesses die every day due to lack of financing.
Fifth point, investment does not make sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are being crushed by austerity measures.
It is the strongest economies that must unleash domestic demand.

It is the case that almost 80% of trade now takes place within Europe. And it is up to the Commission, Commissioner Olli Rehn, to make recommendations addressed not only to the most fragile economies but also to the most dynamic ones.
And finally, Mr. President, we must set a limit on the revenue imposed by the troikas.

It is time to say enough to the punitive, dialogue-less, and unaccountable style in which high-ranking officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member states. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Ladies and Gentlemen of the Commission. What I wanted to say is very clear. Of course, Portuguese MEPs from the EPP fully support all measures that can contribute to growth. There is no possibility of...

if we emerge from this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those states most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I hear some colleagues here, I get the impression that they think growth can continue with excessive deficits and increasing public debt.

Now, we must continue to insist on expenditure reduction and structural reforms. We can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of restraint and reduction of public expenditure.

from structural reforms. More growth cannot be more relaxation, more rest. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and with great rigor in structural reforms.
If we start talking only about growth and thinking there are magical growth solutions, we will end up again with unsustainable public debt and will continue without structural reforms.

With that said, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, at the morning summit, it will not only be a matter of long-term or medium-term growth that is at stake, but also the urgent issue of Greece. I believe it is crucial for the European states to stand by Greece in some way.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem. And I would like to repudiate here the statement made by the British member who spoke of the "Portugalization" of Europe.
the 'Portugalization' of Europe, at least in terms of values, is not a negative thing. Therefore, I reject this idea of trying, ultimately, to humiliate or attempt to diminish any peoples.
We are all Europe, and we all have a place within it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, you have come here to tell us that every additional euro spent on debt is one less euro for job creation. So, please explain to us why we should persist with this obsession.

came here to also tell us that one of the Summit's priorities is to keep Greece in the eurozone. And I ask you, Commissioner, do we believe in you or do we believe Dr. Durão Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who were saying the exact opposite just a few days ago?
You spoke of maintaining the eurozone, but I ask, which euro?

in the euro we currently live in, in this zone we currently inhabit, or in the euro announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study where they referred to a G euro, a second-tier euro, should the left win the elections in June in Greece.
This is a trap, Commissioner, it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by governments, and it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by financial interests.
Let us not allow people to live in fear, for it is no way to live. Europe can be something else. You know, it's not a lack of money, it's a lack of shame.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister Vaman, the first thing I would like to state is that it is regrettable that in a debate of this importance, the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, Ms. Ashton, is not present.
In any case, we are pleased to work once again with Minister Vaman, who made a statement here that I fully endorse.

I would first like to offer a word of comfort and solidarity to the Guinean people, who have essentially been the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically ravaged by democratic instability, political turmoil, and widespread insecurity.
It is not enough that he is surrounded by poverty; he has been systematically affected by these ills.

I meant to say, on the other hand, that the EPP, under your presidency, has been following this issue from the outset, and it is also regrettable that the European Parliament can only manage a debate on this matter after a month.
This is related to the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean issue.

And this invisibility is solely due to the fact that, unlike other equally grave matters, there are no large-scale economic interests at stake here that would prompt European, American, and global powers to discuss the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if an external reason is needed, if the misery and political instability we face are not enough to prompt global humanitarian and political action, there is an external reason.
unless the situation of drug trafficking rampant in Guinea and directly affecting European and American peoples were a reason for us to engage in this.
And, therefore, I ask the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries, the African Union, but perhaps no longer, the Economic Community of West African States, are moving in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, actions are necessary.
We must be more assertive, we must be more effective with the states that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
This is our obligation.

And I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but it is not responding as it should in terms of practical instruments, of operations on the ground, and this is what I am asking of the Council and of the Commission.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, globalization has brought about a disproportionate growth in the financial sector, whose transactions are now, as is well known, seventy times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, the very frequent transactions, the high remunerations, and the very high risk have not only characterized the world we live in today but have also been fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis demanded accountability and efforts from ordinary citizens far more than from the sector that had caused it.
Thus, today, this moment is important.

It is important, and I would personally like to see a situation where the tax is generalized across all countries of the European Union and, subsequently, extended to the rest of the world, through the active involvement of the Commission and the European Union as a whole in the context of the G20.
I would like it to cover, or to include, all products without exception.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary strengthening of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, compromises must be accepted, but we must not lose sight of the direction in which we need to move forward.
And this can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission, and also with a great spirit of compromise on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only express my gratitude here today for the role not only of Ani Podimata, who was tireless in this process, but also of all those who managed to overcome their differences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, colleague Podimata. Today, we are discussing here for the first time the financial transaction tax, and its approval is the first signal that speculation does not go entirely unpunished in this crisis we are living through.
This House and the European institutions must answer to the people, not to financial markets.
For decades, financial market lobbies have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any issues.
It was obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012, the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.

And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to prevent any action from being taken, but also to secure a direct transfer of funds from citizens' pockets straight into these very same speculative markets.

For many years, we have fought for this, Mr. President, but it was only when people across Europe began to say enough is enough that the institutions governing the European Union finally took some initiative.
And therefore, this is the response we must provide to the citizens. It is a first signal we must give.
The citizens of Europe, who have paid for everything, do not deserve to be disrespected.
And therefore, this proposal is not comprehensive, not perfect, will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We, no, European leaders have been apologizing to the financial markets.
They must apologize to the people they have affected.
And, to conclude, Mr. President, quoting a now famous politician, it is about these markets that we speak, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments give a signal of confidence to the people, and I sincerely hope that, with this approval and with the positive vote of my colleagues, we begin to talk about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, muster the courage, let's get this project approved.
Thank you, Mr. President. The financial transactions tax should serve as a means to control and discourage high-risk speculative activities in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and promote healthy competition, the foundation of the single market, while also generating revenue.

The Podimata report sought to align the European Commission's initial proposal with the well-known Stamp Tax in the United Kingdom. In doing so, we made this proposal more appealing to reluctant Member States.
It is expected that the Council also understands the message.

In the Commission's proposal, the tax applied to transactions by financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union. Now, it is intended that transactions in European assets, even those carried out by non-Europeans, should also be taxed.
This measure will broaden the revenue base and reduce leakages.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered a source of own resources for the Union or the States, reducing the taxes of the Member States, a matter yet to be decided.
I conclude, Mr. President, by congratulating the rapporteur on the quality of the work and hope that this symbolic text...
Thank you, Madam President. Over the weekend, we received another request to bail out the private banking sector.

They continue to make the same argument, which is to prevent contagion to the eurozone. And what I ask is whether we have learned nothing. Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and now Spain, and yet contagion persists.
But what kind of contagion-containment root is this that is destroying us?

This policy does not work, we should have known that by now. It is the same government that claims there is no money for culture, education, health, public goods, yet when banks demand it from the markets, it miraculously appears.
This economic policy is not a remedy; it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
Markets rule and governments obey, blackmailing the people. And that is what governments are doing to Greece right now, during an election period.

I sincerely hope that all of us, the Greek people, are well and do not give in to blackmail next Sunday, and that they teach us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, unfortunately, the proposals we discussed here today confirm the ban on crisis-fighting policies in the eurozone and further entrench the logic of the Fiscal Compact Treaty.

There are some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I reiterate, for example, the need for a roadmap for a day when we can begin to consider ways to define possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of eurobonds.
The problem is that this day will only come when all the issues in the eurozone are resolved, and it is taking, and indeed taking a very long time, to arrive.
We support some aspects of this proposal, but at this rate, everything will be too little, too late.
Placing a country under legal protection involves maintaining rates and amounts, as well as prioritizing new loans. In other words, it requires the...
Member states that honor their debt, yet all instruments and resources that could enable their growth and development are withdrawn from them.

Let's be frank with each other. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and is foreseen is for creators, but even that will not be resolved, because it is not effective even for them.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and now Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment, and insolvency. And finally, Mr. President, I would like to state that the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies brings us closer to a point of no return.

In the face of the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German Government propose the same policy to us, but in the form of an overdose. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Many thanks, Mr. President. Given the extremely limited time we have, I would like to simply say to the Commission at this moment that they can count, as they always have, on this...
Parliament in effective action for the solidity of the euro area and Europe, but this can only be achieved when initiatives focusing on discipline are implemented.

We were able to add conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices among the different Member States and among the different citizens, and a hope, a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are going through.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are necessary, and it is these that this Parliament is trying to address. These initiatives focus on investment, growth, and control.
of the sovereign debt that has been the Achilles' heel of the euro area, evidently reflecting the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Mr. Commissioner, you can count on us, the Council, Ms. President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda; it cannot be an agenda that is merely done.
as the discipline or the condition for everything else to follow, nor does it make discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this from us, they can count on the Parliament, and I would like to thank the colleagues again, the rapporteurs, Mr. Gozés, who is the other rapporteur, and all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active elements in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
for a more balanced and robust parliamentary project, which I hope will merit respect, the ability to dialogue, and a spirit of construction and compromise, as it has thus far.
avenged. Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Madam President. Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner.

Thank you very much, Madam President. In addition to thanking all those who collaborated on this result, I would like to request that the final vote be postponed so that we can immediately negotiate at the track level.
Today, one faces three agendas. The growth agenda, the agenda concerning bank management, and the agenda pertaining to sovereign debt management.
And addressing the European Semester means incorporating these three dimensions.
On the issue of growth, I believe it is important to emphasize at this moment that the Commission's recommendations cannot focus solely on...
Countries with deficits. They must also focus on countries with surpluses. If some have to crush their domestic demand, others must release it.

I also believe that, in terms of growth, it is essential for the Commission to monitor the recommendations of the so-called Troika, because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to cut its public investment, to slash public spending, as if nothing had happened.
Triads must have their revenue revised and adjusted based on the results. And I want to tell you, Commissioner, that we approved this today in Parliament.
Parliament, the need to introduce an instrument for growth and counter-cyclical activity amounting to 1% of the European Union's GDP over a 10-year period.
A second fundamental dimension is that of what is now called the Banking Union. We called for this in the Parliament two years ago, in a report from June 2010. So far, it remains to be implemented.

A third dimension is that of sovereign debt. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. I also wish to say that today we have approved the Tupac here, but we have introduced into the Tupac, beyond austerity,

some of the other dimension that has been lacking, and it is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using German terminology, so that the sovereign debt, which exceeds sixty percent, can be managed jointly.

This is a legislative text, and we await the Commission's full support for this Parliament initiative, so that we can control the utterly threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. Now that we intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget citizenship and consumers, in essence, the human and social dimension.

which gives it substance and which was the subject of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Because any growth pact should take into account the social sacrifices and benefits associated with it.

As important as an internal market test, it will be to conduct a social impact test of all measures taken to achieve the single market. A test, indeed, an examination that allows us to measure the progress made for the benefit of European Union citizens.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is undergoing an unprecedented contraction, and unemployment among men, women, and youth is reaching historic highs.
According to forecasts by the Bank of Portugal, the situation will deteriorate in the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Mr. Commissioner Andor.
Emphasizing now and always the basic premise of the need for economic growth, member states will indeed have to focus their efforts on job creation.

The means to achieve this should include subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, reduction of the tax burden on labor, and support for the creation of new businesses and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain employment positions.

It is essential that national employment policies take into account that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are health, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
Urge, as stated in the communication, to bridge the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills demanded by the labor market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment lies in the mobility of workers.
It is also crucial to emphasize the use of structural funds for job creation and the practical significance of the Euros portal as the premier tool for recruitment and job offerings in Europe.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens eagerly await concrete results. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. It is true that six months have passed since this PIB scandal came to light, and what is most unbelievable is that a private company could have managed to...
operating in the market and having introduced silicone implants that were intended for construction and mattress manufacturing and were used in women in 71 countries.
This affected several hundred thousand women, as already mentioned, estimated at around 500,000.

Now, we are talking about estimates because there were failures, and serious failures, in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, it's a fraud, it's a court case, but we also know...

that there is a fraud here that must be addressed by the courts, and the courts will deal with it. But there is a legal loophole, a legal vacuum, and we must address that. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years, we were unable to identify what the criminals were able to identify. And, therefore, there was a void in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of files, in terms of records. Everything failed. But these gentlemen from this company were able to put into practice what we couldn't control.

This process is not merely a matter of the lack of information, which is indeed very important—the lack of information on all matters related to breast implants—but also the humiliation of thousands of women and, in particular, the humiliation of those women who had to undergo tests to determine whether they had received proper implants or not.

We are discussing a matter of public health, and we cannot be lax on such issues. We regulate so many unnecessary things, even the authenticity of spare parts in automobiles, as we recently approved a directive on this matter.

We must control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the Medical Devices Directive is good news. The best news would have been that we did not have to do it. But now, since we are going to do it, let us apply it with...

conditions, with traceability, transparency, control, and sanctions, because, unfortunately, even when applied, these sanctions will not reach the women who have suffered from this issue, and states must take full responsibility.
Mr. President, I would like to state very clearly here that for us, the Council meeting at the end of June is fundamental, and what is essential is that we seek a European solution to this crisis.
From our perspective, the problem thus far is that we have been addressing each emerging issue in isolation and individually.

The time has come for a global solution for Europe, a solution that, as President Dole aptly clarified, hinges on greater integration, enhanced cooperation, closer alignment of European policies, and a revaluation of the community method.
It is fundamental that alongside stability there be growth, but that we do not abandon stability concerns.
We therefore require a comprehensive European response, not a divided response for each state or each region in distress.
Productive issues and increased production possibilities have led to significant rises in milk production, resulting in critical situations, surpluses, and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with high productive potential, these surpluses were sold at bargain prices in the markets of other countries, further exacerbating the downward pressure on prices paid to producers in those countries.

This occurred, for example, with French milk sold in France at twice the price it was sold in Galicia. And producers, faced with the steep rise in the cost of raw materials and production factors, now see their ability to resist low prices extremely reduced.

This is a bad omen for many explorations and productive territories in Europe, and it seems to also be a clear harbinger of what the future might hold without quotas and adequate supply regulation instruments.
It therefore demands a thorough audit of the territorial impacts on thousands of farms across the European Union of abolishing these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the fellow rapporteur on this report.
This is a matter of utmost importance for Europe.
At a time when we are facing a serious economic, financial, and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by combating counterfeit products is crucial for the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation. It should ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All of this with the aim of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years, we have witnessed a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, resulting in annual losses, as already mentioned here, of 250 billion euros for companies and the destruction of 185,000 jobs in the European area.

But, beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also poses a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, as many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc.,
etc., are produced in unregulated environments.
Therefore, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing the entry into the internal market of counterfeit products.
By revising this regulation, it is intended to strengthen the control of the application of the relevant legislation, enhance the legitimacy of its intervention, and increase the...
legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the Regulation to new realities and developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are, therefore, a crucial priority for achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in terms of attaining smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Indeed, the election of the new Egyptian President in the post-Mubarak era is good news. However, we must not be deluded; these presidential elections by no means conclude the ongoing transition process in Egypt.

It has been rightly pointed out that the dissolution of Parliament days before the presidential elections places several risks on the table. And in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Higher Council of...
Armed Forces was a gross understatement. They have legislative power, they have reduced the President's power, and moreover, they still hold the power to define changes to the Constitution.

Now, all this raises some concerns for us and should raise concerns for us because the Egyptians risk becoming hostages to military power and a return to the past, lacking a fundamental element: a democratically elected Parliament.
It is not for us to bring about change in Egypt, but for the Egyptians themselves.
but I believe that we Europeans will have to support all changes that propose the restoration of democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Madam President, dear colleagues, Madam Commissioner. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Lara Come, on the excellent work she has done on this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a rapidly changing world and society, Europe needs a comprehensive, inclusive, effective, and up-to-date standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, enhancing consumer protection and their well-being, while also safeguarding the environment, is essential.

It is also of great importance to have more innovation and social inclusion, as well as the interaction and communication of networks and systems, especially in the field, as already emphasized here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti noted in his report, a new strategy for the single market, European standardization is essential for the governance of the internal market, emphasized.
the need for a revision of the European standardization process, which retains the advantages of the current system and finds the fair balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this regard, the report we are now discussing follows and upholds these objectives, which are the correct and appropriate ones. It aims to eliminate the slowness and fragmentation that currently exist, causing companies to incur costs.

transaction costs and higher unit costs, enhance the participation of SMEs in standardization activities, particularly at the national level, as well as facilitate their access to these standards, and also strengthen

On the other hand, the involvement of parties representing societal interests, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, and people with disabilities, while continuing financial support for European organizations established to represent public interests.

In conclusion, the adoption of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, and to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Many thanks, Mr. President, Ms. Commissioner. The future common fisheries policy should prioritize its environmental, economic, and social sectors.
in a synergistic and non-hierarchical manner, promoting sustainable development and in line with the objectives of smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth as outlined in the EU 2020 Strategy.
As the rapporteur for the Regi opinion, I would like to draw attention to the particularities of certain regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are heavily dependent on the...

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should aim to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thereby safeguarding and preserving the employment that depends on them.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need for an adjustment to this policy and specific measures that should take into account the disparate realities of the fisheries and aquaculture sectors in the various coastal regions.

I advocate for this policy to focus on regionalization as a form of governance, by strengthening the participation of various stakeholders, so that in the future, a more adequate response to the requirements and sensitivities of each maritime basin is possible.
We are approaching the crucial moments in which we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe, and we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable rebalances in our heliotic resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and the promotion of their socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector, and in the provision of quality food, demand more than ever audacity and courageous measures.
We must, therefore, make choices and prioritize goals.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, suggesting that the exploitation of its resources be carried out taking into account scientific data, giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploration, and restricting external access beyond 100 miles to existing fishing banks.
I proposed to protect the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities by rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

I proposed that our communities have greater involvement in the management of their affairs, particularly in fisheries, through the establishment of a dedicated Regional Advisory Council, which would be more suitable for ultra-peripheral regions. I hope that this will lead to a better future for us.

Taking into account what we know about the implementation of the third package and part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the delay in the transposition of its directives, the last information I have is that...

18 Member States have been notified, and this information is likely already outdated due to lack of transposition. The question I put to you is how you view the possibility of, in the legislation being prepared, particularly regarding networks.
trans-European, if it includes a provision, an incentive that sets a condition for the submission of PCIs, of projects of common interest.

conditional upon Member States' compliance with the obligations arising from the third package, or, on the contrary, considers this to be an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left solely to the regular competition mechanisms, Article 101,
and its substitutes, all intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
of the Commission and the tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed in this area. But the question is whether, with legislation in preparation that may...
Would you introduce an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you understand this conditionality to be an abusive instrument, or do you find this conditionality acceptable?
I must admit that I share much of the concern that was initially raised here, regarding the democratic legitimacy and democratic control associated with this proposal from the European Union.

Banking Union and Bank Supervision, because an essential question remains unclear and unresolved, namely the role of the Parliament, the only institution directly elected democratically by the citizens.

But there is another concern I have, which is a fundamental concern and relates to the following. Monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union. However, if everything goes wrong, if banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying for that bankruptcy remains with the taxpayers of the Member States, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a problem of similar importance, it is a fundamental issue that remains unresolved. And lastly, I would just like to mention that the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context we live in, namely inflation, rather than job creation and growth, as it should be, also remains unresolved. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline, and I ask, budgetary discipline, so let's address it. Because what exactly do we mean when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my understanding, budgetary discipline means honoring contracts with pensioners and not abandoning state commitments halfway. In my understanding, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or subsidy cuts.

The budget should honor commitments in health, education, and culture, without closing services or halting and canceling projects midway. Discipline means regulating banks and not taking from taxpayers to give to speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary discipline I would like to see implemented in the European Union, rather than continuing with this market party.

If an example is needed, the budget being discussed in Portugal under the Troika's guidance is a perfect one. It violates all the commitments any state should have towards its citizens in order to respect the closed-door agreements that are bringing Europe and its countries together.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission. Firstly, I would of course like to welcome the results of the Council, although it seems to me that the final decision is somewhat delayed in time, it comes a little late.
The truth is that there is progress.

Now, precisely because I find myself in agreement with everything my colleague Cassolides has said, I would like to pose just one question to the President of the Council. The countries that are under assistance...
Countries facing difficulties have been advocating for the retroactive application of bank debts in their distinction from state debt.
This apparently was not accepted.
But we heard yesterday from the highest German authorities and the highest French authorities that they would treat Ireland as a special case.
What I ask is whether the Council has adopted any decision on discriminatory treatment for Ireland that is different from that reserved for countries such as Portugal, Greece, Spain, and others.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses.
with regard to the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, as we mark the twentieth anniversary of this market.

A first word of thanks to colleagues from all political groups, and in particular to the draftsman of the opinion and the shadow rapporteurs, for their very constructive contributions and their highly positive attitude.
It was a pleasure working with everyone, and the report greatly benefited from our combined efforts.

We are well aware of, and proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been the driving force behind significant economic and employment opportunities in Europe, transforming the lives of European citizens and businesses.
to travel, reside, and work in the Union's space are freedoms within reach of all citizens of the 27 member states.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our businesses, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which translates to more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress the single market has achieved in Europe since its inception in 1992 until the onset of the crisis,
2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the additional 2.13% growth in GDP.
Today, making or receiving a phone call while traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than it was in 2005.
The free movement of people finds its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
Over two and a half million students have benefited from this European Education and Mobility Exchange Program.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative positions due to single market legislation.
But a question arises. Is all well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis affecting us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries living with the drama of unemployment and facing austerity measures, have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative perception of the internal market.
People still do not know or understand their rights sufficiently, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States unjustifiably delay the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thereby hindering its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, seemingly simple matters such as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses following a temporary stay in another EU country, or the opening of a bank account by a student participating in an exchange program...

Erasmus, changing energy suppliers, transferring retirement pensions, recognizing qualifications, and registering a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult, or burdensome procedures.
It is important to address these issues.
That was my concern as the rapporteur.
Therefore, the message in the report is very clear. There is a need for more political will, much more political will from the Member States and European institutions.

Advice, above all advice and coordination between the Council and the Commission, for better and joint governance. It is necessary to regain the trust of citizens and businesses and to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to greet the European Commission, represented by Commissioner Barnier, for the presentation of the Single Market Act 2, 12 priority actions for new growth, which, I am sure, marks a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier, dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your already highly successful efforts.
During the presidency of Jacques Delors at the European Commission, the Single Market of the Union was established in 1992.
Delors then synthesized the three fundamental principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years on, the economic and financial crisis has rekindled the threat of national protectionism, and it has become evident that the internal market is not a finished product.

And the celebration of these 20 years must be seized as an opportunity to relaunch the single market, with a focus on putting the market at the service of the citizen, not the citizen at the service of the market.
For this, it is necessary to define priorities, and I would like to focus on one priority in particular.
It is essential to have a common policy for producing and distributing energy at consumer-accessible prices, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructure, with the possibility of leveraging community investment, which represents added European value.
In energy as well, Madam President, you will subjugate the common market.
One of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which undoubtedly constitutes one of the strongest pillars of the Union's, its member states', and its regions' development.
However, to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies towards equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their increased integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue increasing their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions. However, we will never be able to achieve this if we do not better address our accessibility issues in the area of transportation.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that best address the issues raised by our absence.
We therefore argue that the Commission should consider a specific program akin to POSEI Transportes as an essential instrument for integrating such regions into the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to begin by expressing my sincere gratitude for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and one that demonstrated that the single market is indeed a great achievement of the European project.
I welcome the presence of Minister Mavroianis and his participation in this debate. I thank all colleagues for their constructive stance, some with a skeptical approach, which is understandable.

And to say a very big thank you to Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he brings to the discussion of these issues, these problems of the internal market, and the political will to resolve them.
We still have much to answer to the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, they are disillusioned, and they expect more from us, they expect more from the Council, they expect more from the Commission, they expect more from the Member States.
This assessment is very useful, this 20-year assessment is important, but, as many have said here, it is crucial to open the door to future perspectives.
And the forward-looking perspective encompasses many issues raised here and numerous measures already announced by the European Commission.
The single digital market, citizen mobility, the reform of the EURES portal, the European energy market are examples.

These eloquent facts remind us that we still have a significant journey ahead in the future, and that this path is of utmost importance and vital to addressing the times of crisis we are living through.
Citizens are suffering, and they expect a great deal from politicians and the responses they can provide to the adverse conditions they are facing.
Therefore, it is important that the single market be one of the responses to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment, and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this 20-year celebration, are better equipped to provide the answers our citizens need. Thank you very much.

The Gozés report, together with the report we will draw up on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year, which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential components of the so-called European Semester.

This report discusses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council, upon a proposal from the Commission. And these recommendations, as just mentioned, fall within the context of...
SIXPEC and the future TUPEC, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policy of member countries.

The balance between this control and national autonomy and legitimacy is not easy to achieve and has tilted towards a level of imposition, particularly of discipline, and ultimately may even lead to a serious package of sanctions.

With regard to Tupac, I would briefly like to comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent today, to give its negotiators a negotiating mandate in line with the ambition to quickly finalize this package, this Tupac.

But more European coordination, returning to the subject, means less control by countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure consistency between medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment, and real convergence, and short-term recommendations, focusing primarily on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be consistency.

with the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular regarding the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of certain national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, it is necessary for us to agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic, and labor rights that these recommendations cannot exceed. Lastly, it is important that the quality of the recommendations be assessed based on the results achieved, which is far from the case thus far.

I will finish now, Mr. President. I would just like to thank Mr. Gozés for his collaborative spirit and hope that he takes an additional step in this direction, in order to broaden the consensus base around his report, and that this spirit also remains with regard to the next one.
It is true, and has been mentioned here many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
but there are also many that we already know and it is advisable not to forget them.
We know, for instance, that each shale gas extraction operation uses over 19 million liters of potable water, enough to supply a thousand European citizens for a year in terms of their needs.
We also know that with each shale gas extraction operation, 300 tons, I apologize, of chemicals are pumped into the ground, and approximately 80% of these remain in the soil and do not leave it.

We also know that in each shale gas extraction, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsurface, which, together with the evaporation of the toxic residues resulting from the process, pose a real threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of drinking water resources, and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we understand that the extraction of shale gas is also a response that is seemingly easy, focusing only on the immediate, industry, and profit, while ignoring populations, the future, and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, in this House, that water is an essential, vital, and important resource, that knows how to protect citizens' health and must continue to do so, that seeks to make agreements to prevent emissions and to promote energy efficiency, because we know that environmental and health standards are important.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, prudence is the least one can do.
And they might want to do so, but do not do it in our name or in the name of the citizens who are here for us to represent.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, indeed, recent years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
They showed us that we had a European institutional architecture full of gaps, in particular the institutional architecture of the euro.
And that is why the report presented here and the proposal put forward are so much more ambitious than what is offered by the governments.

However, as the rapporteur also mentioned, we are in the realm of making political choices, and this is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some concerns and will not be able to support this report.
The first has to do with issues related to conditionalities.

What we see and continue to have in our narrative is that solidarity among different countries can only exist when everything is fulfilled in terms of the stability and growth plan, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, the covenant for...

The euro plus is a set of measures that impose nothing other than massive doses of austerity on the peripheries, as well as a set of recessionary measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
A second reason pertains to the Banking Union.

The rapporteur very clearly presents the banking supervision mechanism, but it is so necessary that we cannot avoid the essentials. And the essentials are being overlooked insofar as we continue to add the...

clustered national systems, which means we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong, and therefore taxpayers will continue to pay.
And a third note concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of issuing conventional debt is considered, but only when it is already too late.

because we need the debt as it is now, not just when deficits and excessive debts have been corrected, because with the policies we are following, they will never be corrected; on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire population.

Therefore, Mr. President, I wish to conclude by saying that, despite all efforts, I believe we have a very clear example here that together we could still rise, but divided we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to go even further.
There is always room for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union in recent years has been fundamental.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor to a country with a highly skilled and sophisticated workforce.
But when the country exports, where are the necessary conditions?

And that is why it is important for some countries with surpluses to open their doors to the requalified exports of countries that started from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

A final note to emphasize that it is not feasible for immigration to be the solution, nor for the retrained workforce, which benefited from European Union support, to now be lost through the mass exportation of the most skilled to countries with the means to receive them.
This is dramatic and completely jeopardizes our future. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Small-scale fishing should receive particular protection under the Common Fisheries Policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihoods of many families, but also because it is a factor that keeps these communities anchored along the coastal areas.
Its economic and social sustainability should be a goal, ensuring them a differentiated fisheries regime that prioritizes access to resources.
enables local management and protects the fishing rights benefiting these community's professional fishers from transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important, for its sustainability, to pay attention to the access regime to waters, especially in waters or regions with biogeographic basins.
navies with a reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that should have protected access.

In a context of liberalization and crisis that weighs on fragile regions, it is also necessary to ensure that products from international trade meet the same requirements as those imported by the Union.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, I will be very brief because I believe that what is at stake here is essentially a political issue.
a financial point. And the question that arises is as follows: it is whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or whether we want to exacerbate the crisis.
Most European countries are making a huge effort today, from the perspective of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive manner, in a way that can position their countries...
The European Union, on a global scale, has a high capacity for competition and competitiveness, but it is obvious that without investment, there cannot be growth, and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in the cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge...
effort, they will not be able to grow, and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail. Good accounts with prospects for growth and competitiveness.

The sole and primary instrument for this is precisely this multiannual financial framework. Therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and for its policy to be a model for other countries, we must invest in the budget for the financial perspectives.
